<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Periodic table</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Tabular arrangement of the chemical elements ordered by atomic number</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the table used in chemistry and physics. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Periodic_table_(disambiguation)" title="Periodic table (disambiguation)">Periodic table (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:482px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="638" data-file-width="1205" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg/480px-Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg/720px-Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg/960px-Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg.png 2x" width="480"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-blocks.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Periodic table of the chemical elements</div></div></div>
<p>The <b>periodic table</b>, also known as the <b>periodic table of the</b> (<b>chemical</b>) <b>elements</b>, is a tabular display of the <a href="/wiki/Chemical_element" title="Chemical element">chemical elements</a>. It is widely used in <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">physics</a>, and other sciences, and is generally seen as an <a href="/wiki/Cultural_icon" title="Cultural icon">icon</a> of chemistry. It is a graphic formulation of the periodic law, which states that the properties of the chemical elements exhibit a <a href="/wiki/Periodic_function" title="Periodic function">periodic</a> dependence on their <a href="/wiki/Atomic_number" title="Atomic number">atomic numbers</a>.
The table is divided into four roughly rectangular areas called <a href="/wiki/Block_(periodic_table)" title="Block (periodic table)">blocks</a>. The rows of the table are called <a href="/wiki/Period_(periodic_table)" title="Period (periodic table)">periods</a>, and the columns are called <a href="/wiki/Group_(periodic_table)" title="Group (periodic table)">groups</a>. Elements from the same column group of the periodic table show similar chemical characteristics. <a href="/wiki/Periodic_trends" title="Periodic trends">Trends</a> run through the periodic table, with <a href="/wiki/Nonmetal" title="Nonmetal">nonmetallic</a> character (keeping their own electrons) increasing from left to right across a period, and from down to up across a group, and <a href="/wiki/Metal" title="Metal">metallic</a> character (surrendering electrons to other atoms) increasing in the opposite direction. The underlying reason for these trends is <a href="/wiki/Electron_configuration" title="Electron configuration">electron configurations</a> of atoms.
</p><p>The first periodic table to become generally accepted was that of the Russian chemist <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Mendeleev" title="Dmitri Mendeleev">Dmitri Mendeleev</a> in 1869: he formulated the periodic law as a dependence of chemical properties on atomic mass. Because not all elements were then known, there were gaps in his periodic table, and Mendeleev successfully used the periodic law to <a href="/wiki/Mendeleev%27s_predicted_elements" title="Mendeleev's predicted elements">predict properties of some of the missing elements</a>. The periodic law was recognized as a fundamental discovery in the late 19th century, and it was explained with the discovery of the atomic number and pioneering work in <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum mechanics</a> of the early 20th century that illuminated the internal structure of the atom. With <a href="/wiki/Glenn_T._Seaborg" title="Glenn T. Seaborg">Glenn T. Seaborg</a>'s 1945 discovery that the <a href="/wiki/Actinide" title="Actinide">actinides</a> were in fact f-block rather than d-block elements, a recognisably modern form of the table was reached. The periodic table and law are now a central and indispensable part of modern chemistry.
</p><p>The periodic table continues to evolve with the progress of science. In nature, only elements up to atomic number 94 exist; to go further, it was necessary to <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_element" title="Synthetic element">synthesise</a> new elements in the laboratory. Today, all the first 118 elements are known, completing the first seven rows of the table, but chemical characterisation is still needed for the heaviest elements to confirm that their properties match their positions. It is not yet known how far the table will stretch <a href="/wiki/Extended_periodic_table" title="Extended periodic table">beyond these seven rows</a> and whether the patterns of the known part of the table will continue into this unknown region. Some scientific discussion also continues regarding whether some elements are correctly positioned in today's table. Many <a href="/wiki/Alternative_periodic_tables" title="Alternative periodic tables">alternative representations</a> of the periodic law exist, and there is some discussion as to whether there is an optimal form of the periodic table.
</p>

<li><a href="/wiki/Chalcogen" title="Chalcogen"><span class="nowrap" title="Group 16: O, S, Se, Te, Po, Lv — oxygen group, s² p⁴ elements">16 <i>(chalcogens)</i></span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Halogen" title="Halogen"><span class="nowrap" title="Group 17: F, Cl, Br, I, At, Ts — fluorine group, s² p⁵ elements">17 <i>(halogens)</i></span></a></li>

<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Period_(periodic_table)" title="Period (periodic table)">Periods</a> (1–7, ...)</b></li></ul>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Period_1_element" title="Period 1 element"><span title="Period 1: H, He, Z = 1–2">1</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Period_2_element" title="Period 2 element"><span title="Period 2: Li … Ne, Z = 3–10">2</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Period_3_element" title="Period 3 element"><span title="Period 3: Na … Ar, Z = 11–18">3</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Period_4_element" title="Period 4 element"><span title="Period 4: K … Kr, Z = 19–36">4</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Period_5_element" title="Period 5 element"><span title="Period 5: Rb … Xe, Z = 37–54">5</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Period_6_element" title="Period 6 element"><span title="Period 6: Cs … Rn, Z = 55–86">6</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Period_7_element" title="Period 7 element"><span title="Period 7: Fr … Og, Z = 87–118">7</span></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Extended_periodic_table" title="Extended periodic table"><span title="Periods 8+: Z = 119 …: Afbau, Fricke, and Pyykkö models">8+</span></a></li></ul>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Block_(periodic_table)" title="Block (periodic table)">Blocks</a> (s, p, d, f, ...)</b></li></ul>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<ul><li><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Atomic_orbital" title="Atomic orbital">Atomic orbitals</a></li>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">Overview</span></h2>
<p>The periodic table is a 2-dimensional structured table. The elements are placed in table cells, in reading order of ascending <i><a href="/wiki/Atomic_number" title="Atomic number">atomic number</a></i>. The table columns are called <i><a href="/wiki/Group_(periodic_table)" title="Group (periodic table)">groups</a></i>, the rows are called <i><a href="/wiki/Period_(periodic_table)" title="Period (periodic table)">periods</a></i>. The breaks at the end of each period occur according to a repetition (or periodicity) of physical and chemical properties of the elements.
</p>
<div style="background:#f8f8f8; font-size:90%; border:1px solid #a9a9a9; width:100%; max-width:1800px; margin:0 auto; padding:2px; text-align:center; vertical-align:top; box-sizing: border-box;">
<div style="background:#d8d8d8; padding:2px 1em;font-weight:bold;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-collapse navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Periodic_table" title="Template:Periodic table"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Periodic_table" title="Template talk:Periodic table"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Periodic_table&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div class="navbar-ct-mini"><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Periodic table</a></div></div><div class="mw-collapsible-content">
<table style="border-spacing:1px;display:block;overflow:auto;width:100%;margin:0 !important">
<tbody><tr style="line-height:125%; vertical-align:top;">
<th style="text-align:left; width:5%"><small><a href="/wiki/Group_(periodic_table)" title="Group (periodic table)">Group</a></small>
</th>
<th style="background:#e8e8e8; width:5%"><a href="/wiki/Alkali_metal" title="Alkali metal">1</a>
</th>
<th style="background:#f0f0f0; width:5%"><a href="/wiki/Alkaline_earth_metal" title="Alkaline earth metal">2</a>
</th>
<th style="width:2%"> 
</th>
<th style="background:#e8e8e8; width:5%"><a href="/wiki/Group_3_element" title="Group 3 element">3</a>

<tr style="font-size:85%; line-height:125%; vertical-align:top;">
<td>
</td>
<td style="background:#e8e8e8;">Hydrogen &amp;<br/>alkali metals
</td>
<td style="background:#f0f0f0;">Alkaline earth metals
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td style="background:#e8e8e8;">
</td>
<td style="background:#f0f0f0;">
</td>
<td style="background:#e8e8e8;">

<td style="background:#f0f0f0;">

<td style="background:#f0f0f0;">

<td style="background:#e8e8e8;">

<td><span class="nounderlines"><a href="/wiki/Berkelium" title="Berkelium"><span style="background-color: #9bff99; border-top: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; display: block; line-height: 1.1em; overflow: hidden; padding: 2px 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom;" title="Bk, berkelium"><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:95%; height:2.2em; line-height:1.1em; vertical-align:top;">Berkel­ium</span><span style="color: #000000; display:block;">97</span><span style="display:block; font-size:112%; font-weight:bold;">Bk</span><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:80%; height:1.1em; line-height:1.1em;">​[247]</span></span></a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="nounderlines"><a href="/wiki/Californium" title="Californium"><span style="background-color: #9bff99; border-top: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; display: block; line-height: 1.1em; overflow: hidden; padding: 2px 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom;" title="Cf, californium"><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:95%; height:2.2em; line-height:1.1em; vertical-align:top;">Califor­nium</span><span style="color: #000000; display:block;">98</span><span style="display:block; font-size:112%; font-weight:bold;">Cf</span><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:80%; height:1.1em; line-height:1.1em;">​[251]</span></span></a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="nounderlines"><a href="/wiki/Einsteinium" title="Einsteinium"><span style="background-color: #9bff99; border-top: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; display: block; line-height: 1.1em; overflow: hidden; padding: 2px 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom;" title="Es, einsteinium"><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:95%; height:2.2em; line-height:1.1em; vertical-align:top;">Einstei­nium</span><span style="color: #000000; display:block;">99</span><span style="display:block; font-size:112%; font-weight:bold;">Es</span><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:80%; height:1.1em; line-height:1.1em;">​[252]</span></span></a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="nounderlines"><a href="/wiki/Fermium" title="Fermium"><span style="background-color: #9bff99; border-top: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; display: block; line-height: 1.1em; overflow: hidden; padding: 2px 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom;" title="Fm, fermium"><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:95%; height:2.2em; line-height:1.1em; vertical-align:top;">Fer­mium</span><span style="color: #000000; display:block;">100</span><span style="display:block; font-size:112%; font-weight:bold;">Fm</span><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:80%; height:1.1em; line-height:1.1em;">​[257]</span></span></a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="nounderlines"><a href="/wiki/Mendelevium" title="Mendelevium"><span style="background-color: #9bff99; border-top: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; display: block; line-height: 1.1em; overflow: hidden; padding: 2px 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom;" title="Md, mendelevium"><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:95%; height:2.2em; line-height:1.1em; vertical-align:top;">Mende­levium</span><span style="color: #000000; display:block;">101</span><span style="display:block; font-size:112%; font-weight:bold;">Md</span><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:80%; height:1.1em; line-height:1.1em;">​[258]</span></span></a></span>
</td>
<td><span class="nounderlines"><a href="/wiki/Nobelium" title="Nobelium"><span style="background-color: #9bff99; border-top: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom: 2px dotted #6e6e8e; display: block; line-height: 1.1em; overflow: hidden; padding: 2px 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: bottom;" title="No, nobelium"><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:95%; height:2.2em; line-height:1.1em; vertical-align:top;">Nobel­ium</span><span style="color: #000000; display:block;">102</span><span style="display:block; font-size:112%; font-weight:bold;">No</span><span style="display:block; color:black; font-size:80%; height:1.1em; line-height:1.1em;">​[259]</span></span></a></span>
</td>
<td>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div id="Periodic_table_legend_for_category"></div>
<div id="periodic-table-legend" role="presentation" style="border: 1px solid #a2a9b1; width:100%; line-height:120%; text-align:center; vertical-align:top; font-size:85%; background:#f8f8f8; margin:0; font-size:100%;"><div style="padding:0.3em;">
</div><div style="border-top: 1px solid #a2a9b1;padding:0.3em;">
<span style="text-align:center;display:inline-block; width:8em; border-top:2px solid #6e6e8e; border-bottom:2px solid #6e6e8e; background:#e0e0e0;"><a href="/wiki/Primordial_nuclide" title="Primordial nuclide">Primordial</a></span> <span style="text-align:center;display:inline-block; width:8em; border-top:2px dashed #6e6e8e; border-bottom:2px dashed #6e6e8e; background:#e0e0e0;"> <a href="/wiki/Trace_radioisotope" title="Trace radioisotope"><span class="nowrap">From decay</span></a></span> <span style="text-align:center;display:inline-block; width:8em; border-top:2px dotted #6e6e8e; border-bottom:2px dotted #6e6e8e; background:#e0e0e0;"> <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_element" title="Synthetic element">Synthetic</a></span> <span class="nowrap"><b>Border</b> shows natural occurrence of the element</span> </div><div style="border-top: 1px solid #a2a9b1;padding:0.3em;">
<div style="text-align:left"><span class="nowrap"><b><a href="/wiki/Standard_atomic_weight#Published_values" title="Standard atomic weight">Standard atomic weight</a></b> <i>A</i><sub>r, std</sub>(E)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAAW2013_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAAW2013-1">[1]</a></sup></span><div class="plainlist" style="display: inline-block; vertical-align: top;">
<ul><li>Ca: <span class="nowrap"><span data-sort-value="7001400780000000000♠"></span>40.078</span> — Abridged value (uncertainty omitted here)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAAW2021_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAAW2021-2">[2]</a></sup></li>
<li>Po: [209] — <a href="/wiki/Mass_number" title="Mass number">mass number</a> of the most stable isotope</li></ul></div></div> </div><div style="border-top: 1px solid #a2a9b1;padding:0.3em;">
<table style="width:100%; line-height:1.2em; table-layout:fixed; overflow:hidden; text-align:center;">
<tbody><tr>

</div>
</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Atomic_structure">Atomic structure</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Atom" title="Atom">Atom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png/330px-Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png/495px-Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png/660px-Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Atomic-orbital-clouds_spdf_m0.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>3D views of some <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen-like_atom" title="Hydrogen-like atom">hydrogen-like</a> atomic orbitals showing probability density and phase (g orbitals and higher are not shown)</div></div></div>
<p>The smallest constituents of all normal matter are known as <a href="/wiki/Atom" title="Atom">atoms</a>. Atoms are extremely small, being about one ten-billionth of a meter across; thus their internal structure is governed by <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum mechanics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII2_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-FIII2-3">[3]</a></sup> Atoms consist of a small positively charged <a href="/wiki/Atomic_nucleus" title="Atomic nucleus">nucleus</a>, made of positively charged <a href="/wiki/Proton" title="Proton">protons</a> and uncharged <a href="/wiki/Neutron" title="Neutron">neutrons</a>, surrounded by a cloud of negatively charged electrons; the charges cancel out, so atoms are neutral.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FI2_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-FI2-4">[4]</a></sup> Electrons participate in <a href="/wiki/Chemical_reaction" title="Chemical reaction">chemical reactions</a>, but the nucleus does not.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FI2_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-FI2-4">[4]</a></sup> When atoms participate in chemical reactions, they may gain or lose electrons to form positively- or negatively-charged <a href="/wiki/Ion" title="Ion">ions</a>; or they may share electrons with each other instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Atoms can be subdivided into different types based on the number of protons (and thus also electrons) they have.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FI2_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-FI2-4">[4]</a></sup> This is called the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_number" title="Atomic number">atomic number</a>, often symbolised <i>Z</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> (for "Zahl" — German for "number"). Each distinct atomic number therefore corresponds to a class of atom: these classes are called the <a href="/wiki/Chemical_element" title="Chemical element">chemical elements</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> The chemical elements are what the periodic table classifies and organises. <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">Hydrogen</a> is the element with atomic number 1; <a href="/wiki/Helium" title="Helium">helium</a>, atomic number 2; <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a>, atomic number 3; and so on. Each of these names can be further abbreviated by a one- or two-letter <a href="/wiki/Chemical_symbol" title="Chemical symbol">chemical symbol</a>; those for hydrogen, helium, and lithium are respectively H, He, and Li.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> Neutrons do not affect the atom's chemical identity, but do affect its weight. Atoms with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons are called <a href="/wiki/Isotope" title="Isotope">isotopes</a> of the same chemical element.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> Naturally occurring elements usually occur as mixes of different isotopes; since each isotope usually occurs with a characteristic abundance, naturally occurring elements have well-defined <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atomic_weight" title="Atomic weight">atomic weights</a>, defined as the average mass of a naturally occurring atom of that element.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ciaaw_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-ciaaw-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, 118 elements are known, the first 94 of which are known to occur naturally on Earth at present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[a]</a></sup> Of the 94 natural elements, eighty have a stable isotope; three more (<a href="/wiki/Bismuth" title="Bismuth">bismuth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thorium" title="Thorium">thorium</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>) undergo <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_decay" title="Radioactive decay">radioactive decay</a>, but so slowly that large quantities survive from the formation of the Earth; and eleven more decay quickly enough that their continued trace occurrence rests primarily on being constantly regenerated as intermediate products of the decay of thorium and uranium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[b]</a></sup> The 83 elements that have survived from the formation of the Earth are called <a href="/wiki/Primordial_nuclide" title="Primordial nuclide">primordial</a>. All 24 known artificial elements are radioactive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-2"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electron_configuration">Electron configuration</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Electron_configuration" title="Electron configuration">Electron configuration</a></div>
<p>The periodic table is a graphic description of the periodic law,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri17_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri17-17">[15]</a></sup> which states that the properties and atomic structures of the chemical elements are a <a href="/wiki/Periodic_function" title="Periodic function">periodic function</a> of their <a href="/wiki/Atomic_number" title="Atomic number">atomic number</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[16]</a></sup> Elements are placed in the periodic table by their <a href="/wiki/Electron_configuration" title="Electron configuration">electron configurations</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen2009_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen2009-19">[17]</a></sup> which exhibit periodic recurrences that explain the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_trends" title="Periodic trends">trends</a> of properties across the periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>An electron can be thought of as inhabiting an <a href="/wiki/Atomic_orbital" title="Atomic orbital">atomic orbital</a>, which characterises the probability it can be found in any particular region of the atom. Their energies are <a href="/wiki/Quantization_(physics)" title="Quantization (physics)">quantised</a>, which is to say that they can only take discrete values. Furthermore, electrons obey the <a href="/wiki/Pauli_exclusion_principle" title="Pauli exclusion principle">Pauli exclusion principle</a>: different electrons must always be in different states. This allows classification of the possible states an electron can take in various energy levels known as shells, divided into individual subshells, which each contain a certain kind of orbital. Each orbital can contain up to two electrons: they are distinguished by a quantity known as <a href="/wiki/Spin_(physics)" title="Spin (physics)">spin</a>, which can be up or down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[c]</a></sup> Electrons arrange themselves in the atom in such a way that the total energy they have is minimised, so they occupy the lowest-energy orbitals available unless energy has been supplied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[21]</a></sup> Only the outermost electrons (so-called <a href="/wiki/Valence_electron" title="Valence electron">valence electrons</a>) have enough energy to break free of the nucleus and participate in chemical reactions with other atoms. The others are called <a href="/wiki/Core_electron" title="Core electron">core electrons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:0.5em;">
<tbody><tr>

<td>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Elements are known with up to the first seven shells occupied. The first shell contains only one orbital, a spherical s orbital. As it is in the first shell, this is called the 1s orbital. This can hold up to two electrons. The second shell similarly contains a 2s orbital, but it also contains three dumbbell-shaped p orbitals, and can thus fill up to eight electrons (2×1 + 2×3 = 8). The third shell contains one 3s orbital, three 3p orbitals, and five 3d orbitals, and thus has a capacity of 2×1 + 2×3 + 2×5 = 18. The fourth shell contains one 4s orbital, three 4p orbitals, five 4d orbitals, and seven 4f orbitals, thus leading to a capacity of 2×1 + 2×3 + 2×5 + 2×7 = 32.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup> Higher shells contain more types of orbitals that continue the pattern, but such types of orbitals are not filled in the known elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goudsmit_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-Goudsmit-28">[25]</a></sup> The subshell types are characterised by the <a href="/wiki/Quantum_number" title="Quantum number">quantum numbers</a>. Four numbers describe an electron in an atom completely: the <a href="/wiki/Principal_quantum_number" title="Principal quantum number">principal quantum number</a> <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span> (the shell), the <a href="/wiki/Azimuthal_quantum_number" title="Azimuthal quantum number">azimuthal quantum number</a> <span class="texhtml">ℓ</span> (the orbital type), the <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_quantum_number" title="Magnetic quantum number">magnetic quantum number</a> <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">m</span><sub>ℓ</sub> (which of the orbitals of a certain type it is in), and the <a href="/wiki/Spin_quantum_number" title="Spin quantum number">spin quantum number</a> <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">s</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_order_of_shell_filling">The order of shell filling</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:194px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aufbau_Principle.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="423" data-file-width="425" decoding="async" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Aufbau_Principle.png/192px-Aufbau_Principle.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Aufbau_Principle.png/288px-Aufbau_Principle.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Aufbau_Principle.png/384px-Aufbau_Principle.png 2x" width="192"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aufbau_Principle.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Idealized order of shell-filling (most accurate for <span class="nowrap">  <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span>  ≲ 4 .</span>)</div></div></div>
<p>The sequence in which the orbitals are filled is given by the <a href="/wiki/Aufbau_principle" title="Aufbau principle">Aufbau principle</a>, also known as the Madelung or Klechkovsky rule. The shells overlap in energies, creating a sequence that goes approximately as follows:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ostrovsky_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrovsky-29">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dd>1s ≪ 2s &lt; 2p ≪ 3s &lt; 3p ≪ 4s &lt; 3d &lt; 4p ≪ 5s &lt; 4d &lt; 5p ≪ 6s &lt; 4f &lt; 5d &lt; 6p ≪ 7s &lt; 5f &lt; 6d &lt; 7p ≪ ...</dd></dl>
<p>Here the sign ≪ means "much less than" as opposed to &lt; meaning just "less than".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ostrovsky_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrovsky-29">[26]</a></sup> Phrased differently, electrons enter orbitals in order of increasing <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span> + <span class="texhtml">ℓ</span>, and if two orbitals are available with the same value of <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span> + <span class="texhtml">ℓ</span>, the one with lower <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span> is occupied first.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goudsmit_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-Goudsmit-28">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wong_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wong-30">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>The overlaps get quite close at the point where the d-orbitals enter the picture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci328_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci328-31">[28]</a></sup> and the order can shift slightly with atomic number<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cao_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cao-32">[29]</a></sup> and atomic charge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jorgensen-33">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[d]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting from the simplest atom, this lets us build up the periodic table one at a time in order of atomic number, by considering the cases of single atoms. In <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a>, there is only one electron, which must go in the lowest-energy orbital 1s. This configuration is thus written 1s<sup>1</sup>. <a href="/wiki/Helium" title="Helium">Helium</a> adds a second electron, which also goes into 1s and fills the first shell completely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-2"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>The third element, <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a>, has no more space in the first shell. Its third electron must thus enter the 2s subshell, giving a 1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>1</sup> configuration. The 2s electron is lithium's only valence electron, as the 1s orbital is now too close to the nucleus to participate chemically. The 2s subshell is completed by the next element <a href="/wiki/Beryllium" title="Beryllium">beryllium</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup>). The following elements then proceed to fill up the p-orbitals. <a href="/wiki/Boron" title="Boron">Boron</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>1</sup>) puts its new electron in a 2p orbital; <a href="/wiki/Carbon" title="Carbon">carbon</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>2</sup>) fills a second 2p orbital; and with <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">nitrogen</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>3</sup>) all three 2p orbitals become singly occupied. This is consistent with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hund%27s_rule" title="Hund's rule">Hund's rule</a>, which states that atoms will prefer to singly occupy each orbital of the same type before filling them with the second electron. <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">Oxygen</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>4</sup>), <a href="/wiki/Fluorine" title="Fluorine">fluorine</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>5</sup>), and <a href="/wiki/Neon" title="Neon">neon</a> (1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>6</sup>) then complete the already singly filled 2p orbitals; the last of these fills the second shell completely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-3"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starting from element 11, <a href="/wiki/Sodium" title="Sodium">sodium</a>, there is no more space in the second shell, which from here on is a core shell just like the first. Thus the eleventh electron enters the 3s orbital instead. The 1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>6</sup> core is abbreviated [Ne], as it is identical to the electron configuration of neon: thus sodium's configuration is written [Ne] 3s<sup>1</sup>. <a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">Magnesium</a> ([Ne] 3s<sup>2</sup>) finishes this 3s orbital, and from then on the six elements <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">aluminium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silicon" title="Silicon">silicon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">phosphorus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sulfur" title="Sulfur">sulfur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">chlorine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Argon" title="Argon">argon</a> fill the three 3p orbitals ([Ne] 3s<sup>2</sup> 3p<sup>1</sup> through [Ne] 3s<sup>2</sup> 3p<sup>6</sup>). This creates an analogous series in which the outer shell structures of sodium through argon are exactly analogous to those of lithium through neon, and is the basis for chemical periodicity that the periodic table illustrates:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-4"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup> at regular but changing intervals of atomic numbers, the properties of the chemical elements approximately repeat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri17_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri17-17">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first eighteen elements can thus be arranged as the start of a periodic table. Elements in the same column have the same number of outer electrons and analogous outer electron configurations: these columns are called groups. The single exception is helium, which has two outer electrons like beryllium and magnesium, but is placed with neon and argon to emphasise that its outer shell is full. There are eight columns in this periodic table fragment, corresponding to at most eight outer electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> A row begins when a new shell begins filling; these rows are called the periods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup> Finally, the colouring illustrates the <a href="/wiki/Block_(periodic_table)" title="Block (periodic table)">blocks</a>: the elements in the s-block (coloured red) are filling s-orbitals, while those in the p-block (coloured yellow) are filling p-orbitals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-2"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;">

<td>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#ff9999">2<br/><a href="/wiki/Helium" title="Helium">He</a>
</td>
<td>2×1 = <b>2</b> elements<br/><span style="background:#ff9999; display:inline-block">1s</span> <span style="display:inline-block"><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0p</span></span>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#ff9999">3<br/><a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">Li</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#ff9999">4<br/><a href="/wiki/Beryllium" title="Beryllium">Be</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">5<br/><a href="/wiki/Boron" title="Boron">B</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">6<br/><a href="/wiki/Carbon" title="Carbon">C</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">7<br/><a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">N</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">8<br/><a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">O</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">9<br/><a href="/wiki/Fluorine" title="Fluorine">F</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">10<br/><a href="/wiki/Neon" title="Neon">Ne</a>
</td>
<td><span class="nowrap">2×(1+3) = <b>8</b> elements</span><br/><span style="background:#ff9999; display:inline-block">2s</span> <span style="background:#fdff8c; display:inline-block">2p</span>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="#ff9999">11<br/><a href="/wiki/Sodium" title="Sodium">Na</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#ff9999">12<br/><a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">Mg</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">13<br/><a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">Al</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">14<br/><a href="/wiki/Silicon" title="Silicon">Si</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">15<br/><a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">P</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">16<br/><a href="/wiki/Sulfur" title="Sulfur">S</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">17<br/><a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">Cl</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">18<br/><a href="/wiki/Argon" title="Argon">Ar</a>
</td>
<td>2×(1+3) = <b>8</b> elements<br/><span style="background:#ff9999; display:inline-block">3s</span> <span style="background:#fdff8c; display:inline-block">3p</span>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Starting the next row, for <a href="/wiki/Potassium" title="Potassium">potassium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a> the 4s orbital is the lowest in energy, and therefore they fill it. Potassium adds one electron to the 4s shell ([Ar] 4s<sup>1</sup>), and calcium then completes it ([Ar] 4s<sup>2</sup>). However, starting from <a href="/wiki/Scandium" title="Scandium">scandium</a> the 3d orbital becomes the next highest in energy. The 4s and 3d orbitals are of approximately the same energy and they compete for filling the electrons, and so the occupation is not quite consistently filling the 3d orbitals one at a time. The precise energy ordering of 3d and 4s changes along the row, and also changes depending on how many electrons are removed from the atom. For example, due to the repulsion between the 3d electrons and the 4s ones, at <a href="/wiki/Chromium" title="Chromium">chromium</a> the 4s energy level becomes slightly higher than 3d, and so it becomes more profitable to have a [Ar] 3d<sup>5</sup> 4s<sup>1</sup> configuration than an [Ar] 3d<sup>4</sup> 4s<sup>2</sup> one. A similar anomaly occurs at <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-5"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup> These are violations of the Madelung rule. Such anomalies however do not have any chemical significance,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jorgensen-33">[30]</a></sup> as the various configurations are so close in energy to each other<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci328_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci328-31">[28]</a></sup> that the presence of a nearby atom can shift the balance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-6"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup> The periodic table therefore ignores these and considers only idealised configurations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen2009_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen2009-19">[17]</a></sup>
</p><p>At <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, the 3d orbitals are completely filled with a total of ten electrons. Next come the 4p orbitals completing the row, which are filled progressively by <a href="/wiki/Gallium" title="Gallium">gallium</a> through <a href="/wiki/Krypton" title="Krypton">krypton</a>, in a manner totally analogous to the previous p-block elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIII19_20-7"><a href="#cite_note-FIII19-20">[18]</a></sup> From gallium onwards, the 3d orbitals form part of the electronic core, and no longer participate in chemistry. The s- and p-block elements, which fill their outer shells, are called <a href="/wiki/Main-group_element" title="Main-group element">main-group elements</a>; the d-block elements (coloured blue below), which fill an inner shell, are called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transition_element" title="Transition element">transition elements</a> (or transition metals, since they are all metals).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci326_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci326-36">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>As 5s fills before 4d, which fills before 5p, the fifth row has exactly the same structure as the fourth (though again there are some anomalies when filling the 4d orbitals).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-3"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup>
</p>

</td>

</td>

</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">52<br/><a href="/wiki/Tellurium" title="Tellurium">Te</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">53<br/><a href="/wiki/Iodine" title="Iodine">I</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">54<br/><a href="/wiki/Xenon" title="Xenon">Xe</a>
</td>
<td>2×(1+3+5) = <b>18</b> elements<br/><span style="background:#ff9999; display:inline-block">5s</span> <span style="background:#99ccff; display:inline-block">4d</span> <span style="background:#fdff8c; display:inline-block">5p</span>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The sixth row of the table likewise starts with two s-block elements: <a href="/wiki/Caesium" title="Caesium">caesium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barium" title="Barium">barium</a>. After this, the first f-block elements (coloured green below) begin to appear, starting with <a href="/wiki/Lanthanum" title="Lanthanum">lanthanum</a>. These are sometimes termed inner transition elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci326_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci326-36">[32]</a></sup> As there are now not only 4f but also 5d and 6s subshells at similar energies, competition occurs once again with many irregular configurations;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci328_31-2"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci328-31">[28]</a></sup> this has resulted in some dispute about where exactly the f-block is supposed to begin, but most who study the matter agree that it starts at lanthanum in accordance with the Aufbau principle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen2015_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen2015-37">[33]</a></sup> Even though lanthanum does not itself fill the 4f orbital due to repulsion between electrons,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-3"><a href="#cite_note-Jorgensen-33">[30]</a></sup> its 4f orbitals are low enough in energy to participate in chemistry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hamilton_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hamilton-38">[34]</a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Ytterbium" title="Ytterbium">ytterbium</a>, the seven 4f orbitals are completely filled with fourteen electrons; thereafter, a series of ten transition elements (<a href="/wiki/Lutetium" title="Lutetium">lutetium</a> through <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">mercury</a>) follows,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JensenLr_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-JensenLr-39">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LaF3_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-LaF3-41">[37]</a></sup> and finally six main-group elements (<a href="/wiki/Thallium" title="Thallium">thallium</a> through <a href="/wiki/Radon" title="Radon">radon</a>) complete the period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pyykko_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pyykko-42">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>The seventh row is likewise analogous to the sixth row: 7s fills, then 5f, then 6d, and finally 7p, with a few anomalies along the way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-4"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup> For a very long time, the seventh row was incomplete as most of its elements do not occur in nature. The missing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transuranic_element" title="Transuranic element">elements beyond uranium</a> started to be synthesised in the laboratory in 1940, when neptunium was made.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri354_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri354-43">[39]</a></sup> The row was completed with the synthesis of <a href="/wiki/Tennessine" title="Tennessine">tennessine</a> in 2010<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117s_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-117s-44">[40]</a></sup> (the last element <a href="/wiki/Oganesson" title="Oganesson">oganesson</a> had already been made in 2002),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pp2002_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-pp2002-45">[41]</a></sup> and the last elements in this seventh row were validated and given names in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-20161130_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-20161130-46">[42]</a></sup>
</p>

</td>
<td bgcolor="#99ccff">111<br/><a href="/wiki/Roentgenium" title="Roentgenium">Rg</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#99ccff">112<br/><a href="/wiki/Copernicium" title="Copernicium">Cn</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">113<br/><a href="/wiki/Nihonium" title="Nihonium">Nh</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">114<br/><a href="/wiki/Flerovium" title="Flerovium">Fl</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">115<br/><a href="/wiki/Moscovium" title="Moscovium">Mc</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">116<br/><a href="/wiki/Livermorium" title="Livermorium">Lv</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">117<br/><a href="/wiki/Tennessine" title="Tennessine">Ts</a>
</td>
<td bgcolor="#fdff8c">118<br/><a href="/wiki/Oganesson" title="Oganesson">Og</a>
</td>
<td>2×(1+3+5+7) = <b>32</b> elements<br/><span style="background:#ff9999; display:inline-block">7s</span> <span style="background:#9bff99; display:inline-block">5f</span> <span style="background:#99ccff; display:inline-block">6d</span> <span style="background:#fdff8c; display:inline-block">7p</span>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>This completes the modern periodic table, with all seven rows completely filled to capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-20161130_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-20161130-46">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electron_configuration_table">Electron configuration table</span></h3>
<p>The following table shows the electron configuration of a neutral gas-phase atom of each element. Different configurations can be favoured in different chemical environments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-4"><a href="#cite_note-Jorgensen-33">[30]</a></sup> The main-group elements have entirely regular electron configurations; the transition and inner transition elements show twenty irregularities due to the aforementioned competition between subshells close in energy level. For the last ten elements (109–118), experimental data is lacking<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> and therefore calculated configurations have been shown instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup> Completely filled subshells have been greyed out.
</p>
<table class="mw-collapsible collapsed" style="line-height:120%; text-align:center; background:#f8f8f8; border:1px solid #a9a9a9; margin:0 auto; padding:2px;">
<tbody><tr>

</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Group_names_and_numbers">Group names and numbers</span></h3>
<p>Under an international naming convention, the groups are numbered numerically from 1 to 18 from the leftmost column (the alkali metals) to the rightmost column (the noble gases). The f-block groups are ignored in this numbering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup> Groups can also be named by their first element, e.g. the "scandium group" for group 3.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-1"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup> Previously, groups were known by <a href="/wiki/Roman_numerals" title="Roman numerals">Roman numerals</a>. In America, the Roman numerals were followed by either an "A" if the group was in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S-block" title="S-block">s-</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P-block" title="P-block">p-block</a>, or a "B" if the group was in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D-block" title="D-block">d-block</a>. The Roman numerals used correspond to the last digit of today's naming convention (e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Group_4_element" title="Group 4 element">group 4 elements</a> were group IVB, and the <a href="/wiki/Carbon_group" title="Carbon group">group 14 elements</a> were group IVA). In Europe, the lettering was similar, except that "A" was used if the group was before <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_10_elements" title="Group 10 elements">group 10</a>, and "B" was used for groups including and after group 10. In addition, groups 8, 9 and 10 used to be treated as one triple-sized group, known collectively in both notations as group VIII. In 1988, the new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IUPAC" title="IUPAC">IUPAC</a> naming system (1–18) was put into use, and the old group names (I–VIII) were deprecated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fluck_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fluck-50">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-collapsible uncollapsed" style="background:#f8f8f8; font-size:85%; border:1px solid #a9a9a9; width:100%; margin:0 auto; padding:2px; text-align:center; vertical-align:top;">
<div style="background:#d8d8d8; padding:2px 4px;font-weight:bold;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-collapse navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Periodic_table_(group_names)" title="Template:Periodic table (group names)"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Template_talk:Periodic_table_(group_names)" title="Template talk:Periodic table (group names)"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Periodic_table_(group_names)&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div class="navbar-ct-mini">Groups in the <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Periodic table</a></div></div><div class="mw-collapsible-content">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="2" style="display:block;overflow:auto;width:100%;text-align:center; max-width:1300px; margin:0; padding:0;">

</td>

</td>
<td style="text-align:center; color:#000000; background-color:#fdff8c; border:none; ;" title="Lv, Livermorium"><a href="/wiki/Livermorium" title="Livermorium"><span style="display:block">Lv</span></a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; color:#000000; background-color:#fdff8c; border:none; ;" title="Ts, Tennessine"><a href="/wiki/Tennessine" title="Tennessine"><span style="display:block">Ts</span></a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; color:#000000; background-color:#fdff8c; border:none; ;" title="Og, Oganesson"><a href="/wiki/Oganesson" title="Oganesson"><span style="display:block">Og</span></a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div style="text-align:left; background:#f0f0f0"><span class="anchor" id="Group_1"></span><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1041539562">.mw-parser-output .citation{word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}</style><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_group1"><sup>a</sup></span>  Group 1 is composed of hydrogen (H) and the alkali metals. Elements of the group have one s-electron in the outer electron shell. Hydrogen is not considered to be an alkali metal as it is not a metal, though it is more analogous to them than any other group. This makes the group somewhat exceptional.<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_group3"><sup>n/a</sup></span>  Do not have a group number<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_ScYLu"><sup>b</sup></span>  The composition of group 3 is not agreed among sources: see <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table#Group_3" title="Periodic table">Periodic table#Group 3</a> and <a href="/wiki/Group_3_element#Dispute_on_composition" title="Group 3 element">Group 3 element#Dispute on composition</a>. General inorganic chemistry texts usually put scandium (Sc), yttrium (Y), lanthanum (La), and actinium (Ac) in group 3, so that Ce–Lu and Th–Lr become the f-block between groups 3 and 4. However, sources that study the matter usually put scandium, yttrium, lutetium (Lu), and lawrencium (Lr) in group 3, as shown here. Some sources, including IUPAC, currently follow a compromise that puts La–Lu and Ac–Lr as the f-block rows, leaving the heavier members of group 3 ambiguous. The arrangement with Sc, Y, Lu, and Lr in group 3 has been recommended by a 2021 IUPAC preliminary report on this question.<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_group0"><sup>c</sup></span>  Group 18, the noble gases, were not discovered at the time of Mendeleev's original table. Later (1902), Mendeleev accepted the evidence for their existence, and they could be placed in a new "group 0", consistently and without breaking the periodic table principle.<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_coin"><sup>d</sup></span>  Authors differ on whether roentgenium (Rg) is considered a coinage metal. It is in group 11, like the other coinage metals, and is expected to be chemically similar to gold.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[47]</a></sup> On the other hand, being extremely radioactive and short-lived, it cannot actually be used for coinage as the name suggests, and on that basis it is sometimes excluded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[48]</a></sup><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_IUPAC"><sup>r</sup></span>  Group name as recommended by IUPAC.</div>
</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Presentation_forms">Presentation forms</span></h3>
<div style="border:1px solid grey; float:right; text-align:center; padding:0.2em; margin:0; font-size:90%;">
<div style="background-color:transparent; margin:0; padding:0; text-align:center; border:none;">
<table style="empty-cells:hidden; border:none; padding:0; border-spacing:1px; border-collapse:separate; margin:0;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#ff9999;">Hydrogen</span></a>
</td>
<td colspan="30" style="border:none;padding:0;">
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Helium" title="Helium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#ff9999;">Helium</span></a>
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td colspan="2">

</td>

</td>

</td>

</td>
