</td>
<td style="border:none"><a href="/wiki/Mendelevium" title="Mendelevium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#9bff99;">Mendelevium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none"><a href="/wiki/Nobelium" title="Nobelium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#9bff99;">Nobelium</span></a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>18 columns
</p>
</div>
<p>For reasons of space,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-5"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup> the periodic table is commonly presented with the f-block elements cut out and positioned placed as a distinct part below the main body.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-2"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-6"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fluck_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fluck-50">[46]</a></sup> It reduces the number of element columns from 32 to 18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petrucci331_27-7"><a href="#cite_note-Petrucci331-27">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both forms represent the same periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-3"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> The form with the f-block included in the main body is sometimes called the 32-column<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-4"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> or long form;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup> the form with the f-block cut out the 18-column<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-5"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> or medium-long form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-1"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup> The 32-column form has the advantage of showing all elements in their correct sequence, but it has the disadvantage of requiring more space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup> The form chosen is an editorial choice, and does not imply any change of scientific claim or statement. For example, when discussing <a href="/wiki/Group_3_element#Dispute_on_composition" title="Group 3 element">the composition of group 3</a>, the options can be shown equally (unprejudiced) in both forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-2015IUPAC-56">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>Periodic tables usually at least show the elements' symbols; many also provide supplementary information about the elements, either via colour-coding or as data in the cells. The above table shows the names and atomic numbers of the elements, and also their blocks, natural occurrences and <a href="/wiki/Standard_atomic_weight" title="Standard atomic weight">standard atomic weights</a>. For the short-lived elements without standard atomic weights, the mass number of the most stable known isotope is used instead. Other tables may include properties such as state of matter, melting and boiling points, densities, as well as provide different classifications of the elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[e]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Periodic_trends">Periodic trends</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Periodic_trends" title="Periodic trends">Periodic trends</a></div>
<p>As chemical reactions involve the valence electrons,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-3"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> elements with similar outer electron configurations may be expected to react similarly and form compounds with similar proportions of elements in them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood27_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood27-58">[53]</a></sup> Such elements are placed in the same group, and thus there tend to be clear similarities and trends in chemical behaviour as one proceeds down a group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[54]</a></sup> As analogous configurations return at regular intervals, the properties of the elements thus exhibit periodic recurrences, hence the name of the periodic table and the periodic law. These periodic recurrences were noticed well before the underlying theory that explains them was developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Myers_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-Myers-60">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chang2_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-chang2-61">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>For example, the <a href="/wiki/Valence_(chemistry)" title="Valence (chemistry)">valence</a> of an element can be defined either as the number of hydrogen atoms that can combine with it to form a simple binary hydride, or as twice the number of oxygen atoms that can combine with it to form a simple binary oxide (that is, not a <a href="/wiki/Peroxide" title="Peroxide">peroxide</a> or a <a href="/wiki/Superoxide" title="Superoxide">superoxide</a>). The valences of the main-group elements are directly related to the group number: the hydrides in the main groups 1–2 and 13–17 follow the formulae MH, MH<sub>2</sub>, MH<sub>3</sub>, MH<sub>4</sub>, MH<sub>3</sub>, MH<sub>2</sub>, and finally MH. The highest oxides instead increase in valence, following the formulae M<sub>2</sub>O, MO, M<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, MO<sub>2</sub>, M<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>, MO<sub>3</sub>, M<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[f]</a></sup> The electron configuration suggests a ready explanation from the number of electrons available for bonding,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood27_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood27-58">[53]</a></sup> although a full explanation requires considering the energy that would be released in forming compounds with different valences rather than simply considering electron configurations alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood113_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood113-63">[57]</a></sup> Today the notion of valence has been extended by that of the <a href="/wiki/Oxidation_state" title="Oxidation state">oxidation state</a>, which is the formal charge left on an element when all other elements in a compound have been removed as their ions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood27_58-3"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood27-58">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>As elements in the same group share the same valence configurations, they usually exhibit similar chemical behaviour. For example, the <a href="/wiki/Alkali_metal" title="Alkali metal">alkali metals</a> in the first group all have one valence electron, and form a very homogeneous class of elements: they are all soft and reactive metals. However, there are many factors involved, and groups can often be rather hetereogeneous. For instance, the stable elements of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_group" title="Carbon group">group 14</a> comprise a nonmetal (<a href="/wiki/Carbon" title="Carbon">carbon</a>), two semiconductors (<a href="/wiki/Silicon" title="Silicon">silicon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Germanium" title="Germanium">germanium</a>), and two metals (<a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>). They are nonetheless united by having four valence electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri14_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri14-64">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Atomic_radius">Atomic radius</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:258px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="456" data-file-width="609" decoding="async" height="192" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png/256px-Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png/384px-Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png/512px-Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png 2x" width="256"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Empirical_atomic_radius_trends.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trend in atomic radii</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Atomic_radius" title="Atomic radius">Atomic radii</a> (the size of atoms) generally decrease going left to right along the main-group elements, because the nuclear charge increases but the outer electrons are still in the same shell. However, going down a column, the radii generally increase, because the outermost electrons are in higher shells that are thus further away from the nucleus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-4"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguidear_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-chemguidear-65">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the transition elements, an inner shell is filling, but the size of the atom is still determined by the outer electrons. The increasing nuclear charge across the series and the increased number of inner electrons for shielding somewhat compensate each other, so the decrease in radius is smaller.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguidear_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-chemguidear-65">[59]</a></sup> The 4p and 5d atoms, coming immediately after new types of transition series are first introduced, are smaller than would have been expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood29_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood29-66">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ionisation_energy">Ionisation energy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:514px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="190" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="190" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg/512px-First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg/768px-First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg/1024px-First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg.png 2x" width="512"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Ionization_Energy_blocks.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Graph of first ionisation energies of the elements in electronvolts (predictions used for elements 105–118)</div></div></div>
<p>The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ionisation_energy" title="Ionisation energy">ionisation energy</a> of an atom is the energy required to remove an electron from it. This varies with the atomic radius: ionisation energy increases left to right and down to up, because electrons that are closer to the nucleus are held more tightly and are more difficult to remove. Ionisation energy thus is minimised at the first element of each period – hydrogen and the <a href="/wiki/Alkali_metal" title="Alkali metal">alkali metals</a> – and then generally rises until it reaches the <a href="/wiki/Noble_gas" title="Noble gas">noble gas</a> at the right edge of the period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-5"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> There are some exceptions to this trend, such as oxygen, where the electron being removed is paired and thus interelectronic repulsion makes it easier to remove than expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood294_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood294-67">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the transition series, the outer electrons are preferentially lost even though the inner orbitals are filling. For example, in the 3d series, the 4s electrons are lost first even though the 3d orbitals are being filled. The shielding effect of adding an extra 3d electron approximately compensates the rise in nuclear charge, and therefore the ionisation energies stay mostly constant, though there is a small increase especially at the end of each transition series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguideIE_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-chemguideIE-68">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>As metal atoms tend to lose electrons in chemical reactions, ionisation energy is generally correlated with chemical reactivity, although there are other factors involved as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguideIE_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-chemguideIE-68">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electron_affinity">Electron affinity</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:386px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="552" data-file-width="1050" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg/384px-Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg/576px-Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg/768px-Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg.png 2x" width="384"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Electron_affinity_of_the_elements.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trend in electron affinities</div></div></div>
<p>The opposite property to ionisation energy is the <a href="/wiki/Electron_affinity" title="Electron affinity">electron affinity</a>, which is the energy released when adding an electron to the atom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguideea_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-chemguideea-69">[63]</a></sup> A passing electron will be more readily attracted to an atom if it feels the pull of the nucleus more strongly, and especially if there is an available partially filled outer orbital that can accommodate it. Therefore, electron affinity tends to increase down to up and left to right. The exception is the last column, the noble gases, which have a full shell and have no room for another electron. This gives the <a href="/wiki/Halogen" title="Halogen">halogens</a> in the next-to-last column the highest electron affinities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-6"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some atoms, like the noble gases, have no electron affinity: they cannot form stable gas-phase anions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[64]</a></sup> The noble gases, having high ionisation energies and no electron affinity, have little inclination towards gaining or losing electrons and are generally unreactive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-7"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some exceptions to the trends occur: oxygen and fluorine have lower electron affinities than their heavier homologues sulfur and chlorine, because they are small atoms and hence the newly added electron would experience significant repulsion from the already present ones. For the nonmetallic elements, electron affinity likewise somewhat correlates with reactivity, but not perfectly since other factors are involved. For example, fluorine has a lower electron affinity than chlorine, but is more reactive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguideea_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-chemguideea-69">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electronegativity">Electronegativity</span></h3>
<p>Another important property of elements is their <a href="/wiki/Electronegativity" title="Electronegativity">electronegativity</a>. Atoms can form <a href="/wiki/Covalent_bond" title="Covalent bond">covalent bonds</a> to each other by sharing electrons in pairs, creating an overlap of valence orbitals. The degree to which each atom attracts the shared electron pair depends on the atom's electronegativity<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood25_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood25-71">[65]</a></sup> – the tendency of an atom towards gaining or losing electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-8"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> The more electronegative atom will tend to attract the electron pair more, and the less electronegative (or more electropositive) one will attract it less. In extreme cases, the electron can be thought of as having been passed completely from the more electropositive atom to the more electronegative one, though this is a simplification. The bond then binds two ions, one positive (having given up the electron) and one negative (having accepted it), and is termed an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ionic_bond" title="Ionic bond">ionic bond</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-9"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Electronegativity depends on how strongly the nucleus can attract an electron pair, and so it exhibits a similar variation to the other properties already discussed: electronegativity tends to fall going up to down, and rise going left to right. The alkali and alkaline earth metals are among the most electropositive elements, while the chalcogens, halogens, and noble gases are among the most electronegative ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood25_71-1"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood25-71">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Electronegativity is generally measured on the Pauling scale, on which the most electronegative reactive atom (<a href="/wiki/Fluorine" title="Fluorine">fluorine</a>) is given electronegativity 4.0, and the least electronegative atom (<a href="/wiki/Caesium" title="Caesium">caesium</a>) is given electronegativity 0.79.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-10"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> (Theoretically <a href="/wiki/Neon" title="Neon">neon</a> would be more electronegative than fluorine, but the Pauling scale cannot measure its electronegativity because it does not form covalent bonds.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>An element's electronegativity varies with the identity and number of the atoms it is bonded to, as well as how many electrons it has already lost: an atom becomes more electronegative when it has lost more electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood25_71-2"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood25-71">[65]</a></sup> This sometimes makes a large difference: lead in the +2 oxidation state has electronegativity 1.87 on the Pauling scale, while lead in the +4 oxidation state has electronegativity 2.33.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Metallicity">Metallicity</span></h3>
<p>A simple substance is a substance formed from atoms of one chemical element. The simple substances of the more electronegative atoms tend to share electrons (form covalent bonds) with each other. They form either small molecules (like hydrogen or oxygen, whose atoms bond in pairs) or giant structures stretching indefinitely (like carbon or silicon). The noble gases simply stay as single atoms, as they already have a full shell.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-11"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> Substances composed of discrete molecules or single atoms are held together by weaker attractive forces between the molecules, such as the <a href="/wiki/London_dispersion_force" title="London dispersion force">London dispersion force</a>: as electrons move within the molecules, they create momentary imbalances of electrical charge, which induce similar imbalances on nearby molecules and create synchronised movements of electrons across many neighbouring molecules.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>The more electropositive atoms, however, tend to instead lose electrons, creating a "sea" of electrons engulfing cations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-12"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> The outer orbitals of one atom overlap to share electrons with all its neighbours, creating a giant structure of molecular orbitals extending all over the structure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguidemetal_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-chemguidemetal-75">[69]</a></sup> This negatively charged "sea" pulls on all the ions and keeps them together in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metallic_bond" title="Metallic bond">metallic bond</a>. Elements forming such bonds are often called <a href="/wiki/Metal" title="Metal">metals</a>; those which do not are often called <a href="/wiki/Nonmetal" title="Nonmetal">nonmetals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-13"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> Some elements can form multiple simple substances with different structures: these are called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allotrope" title="Allotrope">allotropes</a>. For example, <a href="/wiki/Diamond" title="Diamond">diamond</a> and <a href="/wiki/Graphite" title="Graphite">graphite</a> are two allotropes of carbon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri14_64-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri14-64">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>The metallicity of an element can be predicted from electronic properties. When atomic orbitals overlap during metallic or covalent bonding, they create both bonding and antibonding <a href="/wiki/Molecular_orbital" title="Molecular orbital">molecular orbitals</a> of equal capacity, with the antibonding orbitals of higher energy. Net bonding character occurs when there are more electrons in the bonding orbitals than there are in the antibonding orbitals. Metallic bonding is thus possible when the number of electrons delocalised by each atom is less than twice the number of orbitals contributing to the overlap. This is the situation for elements in groups 1 through 13; they also have too few valence electrons to form giant covalent structures where all atoms take equivalent positions, and so almost all of them metallise. The exceptions are hydrogen and boron, which have too high an ionisation energy. Hydrogen thus forms a covalent H<sub>2</sub> molecule, and boron forms a giant covalent structure based on icosahedral B<sub>12</sub> clusters. In a metal, the bonding and antibonding orbitals have overlapping energies, creating a single band that electrons can freely flow through, allowing for electrical conduction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siekierski_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Siekierski-76">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>In group 14, both metallic and covalent bonding become possible. In a diamond crystal, covalent bonds between carbon atoms are strong, because they have a small atomic radius and thus the nucleus has more of a hold on the electrons. Therefore, the bonding orbitals that result are much lower in energy than the antibonding orbitals, and there is no overlap, so electrical conduction becomes impossible: carbon is a nonmetal. However, covalent bonding becomes weaker for larger atoms, so silicon and germanium have smaller <a href="/wiki/Band_gap" title="Band gap">band gaps</a> and are <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor" title="Semiconductor">semiconductors</a>: electrons can cross the gap when thermally excited. Finally the band gap disappears in tin, so that tin and lead become metals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siekierski_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-Siekierski-76">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Elements in groups 15 through 17 have too many electrons to form giant covalent molecules that stretch in all three dimensions. For the lighter elements, the bonds in small diatomic molecules are so strong that a condensed phase is disfavoured: thus nitrogen (N<sub>2</sub>), oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>), white phosphorus (P<sub>4</sub>), sulfur (S<sub>8</sub>), and the stable halogens (F<sub>2</sub>, Cl<sub>2</sub>, Br<sub>2</sub>, and I<sub>2</sub>) readily form covalent molecules with few atoms. The heavier ones tend to form long chains (e.g. red phosphorus, gray selenium, tellurium) or layered structures (e.g. carbon as graphite, black phosphorus, grey arsenic, grey antimony, bismuth) that only extend in one or two rather than three dimensions. As these structures do not use all their orbitals for bonding, they end up with bonding, nonbonding, and antibonding bands in order of increasing energy. Similarly to group 14, the band gaps shrink for the heavier elements and free movement of electrons between the chains or layers becomes possible. Thus for example black phosphorus, black arsenic, grey selenium, tellurium, and iodine are semiconductors; grey arsenic, grey antimony, and bismuth are <a href="/wiki/Semimetal" title="Semimetal">semimetals</a> (exhibiting quasi-metallic conduction, with a very small band overlap); and polonium and probably astatine are true metals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siekierski_76-2"><a href="#cite_note-Siekierski-76">[70]</a></sup> Finally, the natural group 18 elements all stay as individual atoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siekierski_76-3"><a href="#cite_note-Siekierski-76">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[g]</a></sup>
</p><p>The dividing line between metals and nonmetals is roughly diagonal from top left to bottom right, with the transition series appearing to the left of this diagonal (as they have many available orbitals for overlap). This is expected, as metallicity tends to be correlated with electropositivity and the willingness to lose electrons, which increases right to left and up to down. Thus the metals greatly outnumber the nonmetals. Elements near the borderline are difficult to classify: they tend to have properties that are intermediate between those of metals and nonmetals, and may have some properties characteristic of both. They are often termed semimetals or <a href="/wiki/Metalloid" title="Metalloid">metalloids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-14"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> The term "semimetal" used in this sense should not be confused with its strict physical sense having to do with band structure: bismuth is physically a semimetal, but is generally considered a metal by chemists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>The following table considers the most stable allotropes at standard conditions. The elements coloured yellow form simple substances that are well-characterised by metallic bonding. Elements coloured light blue form giant covalent structures, whereas those coloured dark blue form small covalently bonded molecules that are held together by weaker <a href="/wiki/Van_der_Waals_force" title="Van der Waals force">van der Waals forces</a>. The noble gases are coloured in violet: their molecules are single atoms and no covalent bonding occurs. Greyed-out cells are for elements which have not been prepared in sufficient quantities for their most stable allotropes to have been characterised in this way. Theoretical considerations suggest that all (or at least almost all) of those elements would metallise if they could form condensed phases,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siekierski_76-5"><a href="#cite_note-Siekierski-76">[70]</a></sup> although this has been questioned for copernicium,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eichler_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eichler-80">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hcp_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-hcp-81">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bcc_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-bcc-82">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRNL_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-CRNL-84">[77]</a></sup> flerovium,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[78]</a></sup> and oganesson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-semiconductor_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-semiconductor-86">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[h]</a></sup>
</p>

</td>
<td style="text-align:center; color:#000000; background-color:#eee8aa; border:2px solid #6e6e8e; ;" title="Rh, rhodium"><a href="/wiki/Rhodium" title="Rhodium"><span style="display:block">Rh</span></a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; color:#000000; background-color:#eee8aa; border:2px solid #6e6e8e; ;" title="Pd, palladium"><a href="/wiki/Palladium" title="Palladium"><span style="display:block">Pd</span></a>
</td>

<div id="periodic-table-legend" role="presentation" style="border: 1px solid #a2a9b1; width:100%; line-height:120%; text-align:center; vertical-align:top; font-size:85%; background:#f8f8f8; margin:0;"><div style="padding:0.3em;">
<p><span style="display: inline-block;">
<span style="display: inline-block; width:*; background:#eee8aa"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metallic_bond" title="Metallic bond">Metallic</a></span>
<span style="display: inline-block; width:*; background:#b0e0e6">Giant <a href="/wiki/Covalent_bond" title="Covalent bond">covalent</a></span>
<span style="display: inline-block; width:*; background:#b0c0e6">Molecular covalent</span>
<span style="display: inline-block; width:*; background:#e0b0e6">Single atoms</span>
<span style="display: inline-block; width:*; padding:0 0.5em; background:#e8e8e8">Unknown</span>
</span><span style="display: inline-block;"><b>Background color</b> shows bonding of simple substances in the <a class="mw-selflink selflink">periodic table</a></span>
</p>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 194.66666666667px"><div style="width: 194.66666666667px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 192.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg" title="Iron, a metal"><img alt="Iron, a metal" data-file-height="3197" data-file-width="5135" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg/289px-Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg/434px-Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg/579px-Iron_electrolytic_and_1cm3_cube.jpg 2x" width="193"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 146px"><div style="width: 146px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 144px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine,_San_Pablo_de_Napa,_Daniel_Campos_Province,_Potos%C3%AD,_Bolivia.jpg" title="Sulfur, a nonmetal"><img alt="Sulfur, a nonmetal" data-file-height="5000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine%2C_San_Pablo_de_Napa%2C_Daniel_Campos_Province%2C_Potos%C3%AD%2C_Bolivia.jpg/216px-Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine%2C_San_Pablo_de_Napa%2C_Daniel_Campos_Province%2C_Potos%C3%AD%2C_Bolivia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine%2C_San_Pablo_de_Napa%2C_Daniel_Campos_Province%2C_Potos%C3%AD%2C_Bolivia.jpg/324px-Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine%2C_San_Pablo_de_Napa%2C_Daniel_Campos_Province%2C_Potos%C3%AD%2C_Bolivia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine%2C_San_Pablo_de_Napa%2C_Daniel_Campos_Province%2C_Potos%C3%AD%2C_Bolivia.jpg/432px-Sulfur_-_El_Desierto_mine%2C_San_Pablo_de_Napa%2C_Daniel_Campos_Province%2C_Potos%C3%AD%2C_Bolivia.jpg 2x" width="144"/></a></div></div>

</p>
</div>
