<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 211.33333333333px"><div style="width: 211.33333333333px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 209.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arsen_1a.jpg" title="Arsenic, an element often called a semi-metal or metalloid"><img alt="Arsenic, an element often called a semi-metal or metalloid" data-file-height="255" data-file-width="445" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Arsen_1a.jpg/314px-Arsen_1a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7b/Arsen_1a.jpg 1.5x" width="210"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Arsenic, an element often called a semi-metal or metalloid
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<p>Generally, metals are shiny and dense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-15"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> They usually have high melting and boiling points due to the strength of the metallic bond, and are often malleable and ductile (easily stretched and shaped) because the atoms can move relative to each other without breaking the metallic bond.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguidem_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-chemguidem-89">[81]</a></sup> They conduct electricity because their electrons are free to move in all three dimensions. Similarly, they conduct heat, which is transferred by the electrons as extra <a href="/wiki/Kinetic_energy" title="Kinetic energy">kinetic energy</a>: they move faster. These properties persist in the liquid state, as although the crystal structure is destroyed on melting, the atoms still touch and the metallic bond persists, though it is weakened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chemguidem_89-1"><a href="#cite_note-chemguidem-89">[81]</a></sup> Metals tend to be reactive towards nonmetals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-16"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> Some exceptions can be found to these generalisations: for example, manganese,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holl_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-Holl-90">[82]</a></sup> arsenic, antimony,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiberg_holleman_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-wiberg_holleman-91">[83]</a></sup> and bismuth are brittle;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRC_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-CRC-92">[84]</a></sup> chromium is extremely hard;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-r1_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-r1-93">[85]</a></sup> gallium, rubidium, caesium, and mercury are liquid at or close to room temperature;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[i]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Noble_metal" title="Noble metal">noble metals</a> such as gold are chemically very inert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nonmetals exhibit different properties. Those forming giant covalent crystals exhibit high melting and boiling points, as it takes considerable energy to overcome the strong covalent bonds. Those forming discrete molecules are held together mostly by dispersion forces, which are more easily overcome; thus they tend to have lower melting and boiling points,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[88]</a></sup> and many are liquids or gases at room temperature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-17"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> Nonmetals are often dull-looking. They tend to be reactive towards metals, except for the noble gases, which are inert towards most substances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-18"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> They are brittle when solid as their atoms are held tightly in place. They are less dense and conduct electricity poorly,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-19"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> because there are no mobile electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-group4_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-group4-98">[89]</a></sup> Near the borderline, band gaps are small and thus many elements in that region are semiconductors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-group4_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-group4-98">[89]</a></sup> Again there are exceptions; for example, diamond has the highest thermal conductivity of all known materials, greater than any metal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNU_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-PNU-99">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is common to designate a class of metalloids straddling the boundary between metals and nonmetals, as elements in that region are intermediate in both physical and chemical properties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cartoon_5-20"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon-5">[5]</a></sup> However, no consensus exists in the literature for precisely which elements should be so designated. When such a category is used, boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony, and tellurium are usually included; but most sources include other elements as well, without agreement on which extra elements should be added, and some others subtract from this list instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[j]</a></sup> For example, the periodic table used by the American Chemical Society includes polonium as a metalloid,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACS_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-ACS-101">[91]</a></sup> but that used by the Royal Society of Chemistry does not,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[92]</a></sup> and that included in the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i> does not refer to metalloids or semi-metals at all.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-103">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[k]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_manifestations_of_periodicity">Further manifestations of periodicity</span></h3>
<p>There are some other relationships throughout the periodic table between elements that are not in the same group, such as the <a href="/wiki/Diagonal_relationship" title="Diagonal relationship">diagonal relationships</a> between elements that are diagonally adjacent (e.g. lithium and magnesium).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS2_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS2-106">[95]</a></sup> Some similarities can also be found between the main groups and the transition metal groups, or between the early actinides and early transition metals, when the elements have the same number of valence electrons. Thus uranium somewhat resembles chromium and tungsten in group 6,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS2_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS2-106">[95]</a></sup> as all three have six valence electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen-107">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first row of every block tends to show rather distinct properties from the other rows, because the first orbital of each type (1s, 2p, 3d, 4f, 5g, etc.) is significantly smaller than would be expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaupp_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kaupp-108">[97]</a></sup> The degree of the anomaly is highest for the s-block, is moderate for the p-block, and is less pronounced for the d- and f-blocks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS2_106-2"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS2-106">[95]</a></sup> There is also an even-odd difference between the periods (except in the s-block) that is sometimes known as secondary periodicity: elements in even periods have smaller atomic radii and prefer to lose fewer electrons, while elements in odd periods (except the first) differ in the opposite direction. Thus, many properties in the p-block show a zigzag rather than a smooth trend along the group. For example, phosphorus and antimony in odd periods of group 15 readily reach the +5 oxidation state, whereas nitrogen, arsenic, and bismuth in even periods prefer to stay at +3.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS2_106-3"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS2-106">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-primefan_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-primefan-109">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1311" data-file-width="1209" decoding="async" height="239" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg/220px-Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg/330px-Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg/440px-Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pouring_liquid_mercury_bionerd.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Flowing liquid mercury. Its liquid state at room temperature is a result of special relativity.</div></div></div>
<p>When atomic nuclei become highly charged, <a href="/wiki/Special_relativity" title="Special relativity">special relativity</a> becomes needed to gauge the effect of the nucleus on the electron cloud. These <a href="/wiki/Relativistic_quantum_chemistry" title="Relativistic quantum chemistry">relativistic effects</a> result in heavy elements increasingly having differing properties compared to their lighter homologues in the periodic table. For example, relativistic effects explain why <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> is golden and <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">mercury</a> is a liquid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PekkaPyykko_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-PekkaPyykko-110">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norrby_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-Norrby-111">[100]</a></sup> These effects are expected to become very strong in the late seventh period, potentially leading to a collapse of periodicity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-primefan2_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-primefan2-112">[101]</a></sup> Electron configurations and chemical properties are only clearly known till element 108 (<a href="/wiki/Hassium" title="Hassium">hassium</a>), so the chemical characterisation of the heaviest elements remains a topic of current research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schändel_2003_277_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schändel_2003_277-113">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many other physical properties of the elements exhibit periodic variation in accordance with the periodic law, such as <a href="/wiki/Melting_point" title="Melting point">melting points</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boiling_point" title="Boiling point">boiling points</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heat_of_fusion" title="Heat of fusion">heats of fusion</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heat_of_vaporisation" title="Heat of vaporisation">heats of vaporisation</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atomisation_energy" title="Atomisation energy">atomisation energy</a>, and so on. Similar periodic variations appear for the compounds of the elements, which can be observed by comparing hydrides, oxides, sulfides, halides, and so on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood25_71-3"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood25-71">[65]</a></sup> Chemical properties are more difficult to describe quantitatively, but likewise exhibit their own periodicities. Examples include how oxidation states tend to vary in steps of 2 in the main-group elements, but in steps of 1 for the transition elements; the variation in the <a href="/wiki/Acid" title="Acid">acidic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Base_(chemistry)" title="Base (chemistry)">basic</a> properties of the elements and their compounds; the stabilities of compounds; and methods of isolating the elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood27_58-4"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood27-58">[53]</a></sup> Periodicity is and has been used very widely to predict the properties of unknown new elements and new compounds, and is central to modern chemistry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood29bis_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood29bis-114">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Classification_of_elements">Classification of elements</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:514px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="638" data-file-width="1205" decoding="async" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg/512px-Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg/768px-Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg/1024px-Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg.png 2x" width="512"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Simple_Periodic_Table_Chart-en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A periodic table colour-coded to show some commonly used sets of similar elements. The categories and their boundaries differ somewhat between sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACS_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-ACS-101">[91]</a></sup><div> <table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;"> <tbody><tr> <td style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff9d9d; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alkali_metals" title="Alkali metals">Alkali metals</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffdead; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alkaline_earth_metals" title="Alkaline earth metals">Alkaline earth metals</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffbfff; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lanthanides" title="Lanthanides">Lanthanides</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff99cc; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Actinides" title="Actinides">Actinides</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffc0c0; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transition_metals" title="Transition metals">Transition metals</a> </td> <td style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#cccccc; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Other_metals" title="Other metals">Other metals</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#cccc99; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metalloids" title="Metalloids">Metalloids</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#a0ffa0; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Other_nonmetal" title="Other nonmetal">Other nonmetals</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffff99; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Halogens" title="Halogens">Halogens</a><br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#c0ffff; color:black;"> </span> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Noble_gases" title="Noble gases">Noble gases</a> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></div>
<p>Many terms have been used in the literature to describe sets of elements that behave similarly. The group names <i>alkali metal</i>, <i>alkaline earth metal</i>, <i>pnictogen</i>, <i>chalcogen</i>, <i>halogen</i>, and <i>noble gas</i>  are acknowledged by IUPAC; the other groups can be referred to by their number, or by their first element (e.g., group 6 is the chromium group).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-2"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup> Some divide the p-block elements from groups 13 to 16 by metallicity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-EB-103">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACS_101-2"><a href="#cite_note-ACS-101">[91]</a></sup> although there is neither a IUPAC definition nor a precise consensus on exactly which elements should be considered metals, nonmetals, or semi-metals (sometimes called metalloids).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_103-2"><a href="#cite_note-EB-103">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACS_101-3"><a href="#cite_note-ACS-101">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-3"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup> Neither is there a consensus on what the metals succeeding the transition metals ought to be called, with <i>post-transition metal</i> and <i>poor metal</i> being among the possibilities having been used.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[l]</a></sup> Some advanced monographs exclude the elements of group 12 from the transition metals on the grounds of their sometimes quite different chemical properties, but this is not a universal practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i>lanthanides</i> are considered to be the elements La–Lu, which are all very similar to each other: historically they included only Ce–Lu, but lanthanum became included by common usage. The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rare_earth_element" title="Rare earth element">rare earth elements</a></i> (or rare earth metals) add scandium and yttrium to the lanthanides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-4"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup> Analogously, the <i>actinides</i> are considered to be the elements Ac–Lr (historically Th–Lr),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-5"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup> although variation of properties in this set is much greater than within the lanthanides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-5"><a href="#cite_note-Jorgensen-33">[30]</a></sup> IUPAC recommends the names <i>lanthanoids</i> and <i>actinoids</i> to avoid ambiguity, as the -ide suffix typically denotes a negative ion; however <i>lanthanides</i> and <i>actinides</i> remain common.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC_49-6"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-49">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many more categorisations exist and are used according to certain disciplines. In astrophysics, a metal is defined as any element with atomic number greater than 2, i.e. anything except hydrogen and helium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[105]</a></sup> The term "semimetal" has a different definition in physics than it does in chemistry: bismuth is a semimetal by physical definitions, but chemists generally consider it a metal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[106]</a></sup> A few terms are widely used, but without any very formal definition, such as "<a href="/wiki/Heavy_metals" title="Heavy metals">heavy metal</a>", which has been given such a wide range of definitions that it has been criticised as "effectively meaningless".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>The scope of terms varies significantly between authors. For example, according to IUPAC, the noble gases extend to include the whole group, including the very radioactive superheavy element oganesson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[108]</a></sup> However, among those who specialise in the superheavy elements, this is not often done: in this case "noble gas" is typically taken to imply the unreactive behaviour of the lighter elements of the group. Since calculations generally predict that oganesson should not be particularly inert due to relativistic effects, and may not even be a gas at room temperature if it could be produced in bulk, its status as a noble gas is often questioned in this context.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[109]</a></sup> Furthermore, national variations are sometimes encountered: in Japan, alkaline earth metals often do not include beryllium and magnesium as their behaviour is different from the heavier group 2 metals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_periodic_table" title="History of the periodic table">History of the periodic table</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_chemical_element_discoveries" title="Timeline of chemical element discoveries">Timeline of chemical element discoveries</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:258px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1869-periodic-table.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1312" data-file-width="1067" decoding="async" height="315" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/1869-periodic-table.jpg/256px-1869-periodic-table.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/1869-periodic-table.jpg/384px-1869-periodic-table.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/1869-periodic-table.jpg/512px-1869-periodic-table.jpg 2x" width="256"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1869-periodic-table.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mendeleev's 1869 periodic table</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<p>In 1817, German physicist <a href="/wiki/Johann_Wolfgang_D%C3%B6bereiner" title="Johann Wolfgang Döbereiner">Johann Wolfgang Döbereiner</a> began to formulate one of the earliest attempts to classify the elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[111]</a></sup> In 1829, he found that he could form some of the elements into groups of three, with the members of each group having related properties. He termed these groups <a href="/wiki/D%C3%B6bereiner%27s_triads" title="Döbereiner's triads">triads</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[113]</a></sup> Chlorine, bromine, and iodine formed a triad; as did calcium, strontium, and barium; lithium, sodium, and potassium; and sulfur, selenium, and tellurium. Today, all these triads form part of modern-day groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[114]</a></sup> Various chemists continued his work and were able to identify more and more relationships between small groups of elements. However, they could not build one scheme that encompassed them all.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>German chemist <a href="/wiki/Lothar_Meyer" title="Lothar Meyer">Lothar Meyer</a> noted the sequences of similar chemical and physical properties repeated at periodic intervals. According to him, if the atomic weights were plotted as ordinates (i.e. vertically) and the atomic volumes as abscissas (i.e. horizontally)—the curve obtained a series of maximums and minimums—the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electropositive" title="Electropositive">electropositive</a> elements would appear at the peaks of the curve in the order of their atomic weights. In 1864, a book of his was published; it contained an early version of the periodic table containing 28 elements, and classified elements into six families by their <a href="/wiki/Valence_(chemistry)" title="Valence (chemistry)">valence</a>—for the first time, elements had been grouped according to their valence. Works on organizing the elements by atomic weight had until then been stymied by inaccurate measurements of the atomic weights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meyer_table_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Meyer_table-128">[116]</a></sup> In 1868, he revised his table, but this revision was published as a draft only after his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:514px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mendelejevs_periodiska_system_1871.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="341" data-file-width="684" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Mendelejevs_periodiska_system_1871.png/512px-Mendelejevs_periodiska_system_1871.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/55/Mendelejevs_periodiska_system_1871.png 1.5x" width="512"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mendelejevs_periodiska_system_1871.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mendeleev's 1871 periodic table</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mendeleev">Mendeleev</span></h3>
<p>The definitive breakthrough came from the Russian chemist <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Mendeleev" title="Dmitri Mendeleev">Dmitri Mendeleev</a>. Although other chemists (including Meyer) had found some other versions of the periodic system at about the same time, Mendeleev was the most dedicated to developing and defending his system, and it was his system that most impacted the scientific community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[118]</a></sup> On 17 February 1869 (1 March 1869 in the Gregorian calendar), Mendeleev began arranging the elements and comparing them by their atomic weights. He began with a few elements, and over the course of the day his system grew till it encompassed most of the known elements. After finding a consistent arrangement, his printed table appeared in May 1869 in the journal of the Russian Chemical Society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri117_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri117-131">[119]</a></sup> In some cases, there appeared to be an element missing from the system, and he boldly predicted that that meant that the element had yet to be discovered. In 1871, Mendeleev published a long article, including an updated form of his table, that made his predictions for unknown elements explicit. Mendeleev predicted the properties of three of these unknown elements in detail: as they would be missing heavier homologues of boron, aluminium, and silicon, he named them eka-boron, eka-aluminium, and eka-silicon ("eka" being Sanskrit for "one").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri117_131-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri117-131">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mendeleev1871_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-mendeleev1871-132">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 45">: 45 </span></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DIMendeleevCab.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1593" data-file-width="1134" decoding="async" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/DIMendeleevCab.jpg/220px-DIMendeleevCab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/DIMendeleevCab.jpg/330px-DIMendeleevCab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/DIMendeleevCab.jpg/440px-DIMendeleevCab.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DIMendeleevCab.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Dmitri Mendeleev</div></div></div>
<p>In 1875, the French chemist <a href="/wiki/Paul-%C3%89mile_Lecoq_de_Boisbaudran" title="Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran">Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran</a>, working without knowledge of Mendeleev's prediction, discovered a new element in a sample of the mineral <a href="/wiki/Sphalerite" title="Sphalerite">sphalerite</a>, and named it gallium. He isolated the element and began determining its properties. Mendeleev, reading de Boisbaudran's publication, sent a letter claiming that gallium was his predicted eka-aluminium. Although Lecoq de Boisbaudran was initially sceptical, and suspected that Mendeleev was trying to take credit for his discovery, he later admitted that Mendeleev was correct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[121]</a></sup> In 1879, the Swedish chemist <a href="/wiki/Lars_Fredrik_Nilson" title="Lars Fredrik Nilson">Lars Fredrik Nilson</a> discovered a new element, which he named scandium: it turned out to be eka-boron. Eka-silicon was found in 1886 by German chemist <a href="/wiki/Clemens_Winkler" title="Clemens Winkler">Clemens Winkler</a>, who named it germanium. The properties of gallium, scandium, and germanium matched what Mendeleev had predicted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[122]</a></sup> In 1889, Mendeleev noted at the Faraday Lecture to the Royal Institution in London that he had not expected to live long enough "to mention their discovery to the Chemical Society of Great Britain as a confirmation of the exactitude and generality of the periodic law".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[123]</a></sup> Even the discovery of the noble gases at the close of the 19th century, which Mendeleev had not predicted, fitted neatly into his scheme as an eighth main group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri164_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri164-136">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mendeleev nevertheless had some trouble fitting the known lanthanides into his scheme, as they did not exhibit the periodic change in valencies that the other elements did. After much investigation, the Czech chemist <a href="/wiki/Bohuslav_Brauner" title="Bohuslav Brauner">Bohuslav Brauner</a> suggested in 1902 that the lanthanides could all be placed together in one group on the periodic table. He named this the "asteroid hypothesis" as an astronomical analogy: just as there is an <a href="/wiki/Asteroid_belt" title="Asteroid belt">asteroid belt</a> instead of a single planet between Mars and Jupiter, so the place below yttrium was occupied by all the lanthanides instead of just one element.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-2"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Atomic_number">Atomic number</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Henry_Moseley_(1887-1915).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="420" data-file-width="546" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Henry_Moseley_%281887-1915%29.jpg/220px-Henry_Moseley_%281887-1915%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Henry_Moseley_%281887-1915%29.jpg/330px-Henry_Moseley_%281887-1915%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Henry_Moseley_%281887-1915%29.jpg/440px-Henry_Moseley_%281887-1915%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Henry_Moseley_(1887-1915).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Henry Moseley</div></div></div><p>
After the internal structure of the atom was probed, amateur Dutch physicist <a href="/wiki/Antonius_van_den_Broek" title="Antonius van den Broek">Antonius van den Broek</a> proposed in 1913 that the nuclear charge determined the placement of elements in the periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moseley2010_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-moseley2010-137">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[126]</a></sup> The New Zealand physicist <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Rutherford" title="Ernest Rutherford">Ernest Rutherford</a> coined the word "atomic number" for this nuclear charge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[127]</a></sup> In van der Broek's published article he illustrated the first electronic periodic table showing the elements arranged according to the number of their electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[128]</a></sup> Rutherford confirmed in his 1914 paper that Bohr had accepted the view of van der Broek.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[129]</a></sup> </p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="982" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg/220px-Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg/330px-Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg/440px-Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Extended_periodic_table_van_den_Broek.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Periodic table of van den Broek</div></div></div>
<p>The same year, English physicist <a href="/wiki/Henry_Moseley" title="Henry Moseley">Henry Moseley</a> using <a href="/wiki/X-ray_spectroscopy" title="X-ray spectroscopy">X-ray spectroscopy</a> confirmed van den Broek's proposal experimentally. Moseley determined the value of the nuclear charge of each element from <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">aluminium</a> to <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> and showed that Mendeleev's ordering actually places the elements in sequential order by nuclear charge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[130]</a></sup> Nuclear charge is identical to <a href="/wiki/Proton" title="Proton">proton</a> count and determines the value of the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_number" title="Atomic number">atomic number</a> (<i>Z</i>) of each element. Using atomic number gives a definitive, integer-based sequence for the elements. Moseley's research immediately resolved discrepancies between atomic weight and chemical properties; these were cases such as tellurium and iodine, where atomic number increases but atomic weight decreases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moseley2010_137-1"><a href="#cite_note-moseley2010-137">[125]</a></sup> Although Moseley was soon killed in World War I, the Swedish physicist <a href="/wiki/Manne_Siegbahn" title="Manne Siegbahn">Manne Siegbahn</a> continued his work up to <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, and established that it was the element with the highest atomic number then known (92).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[131]</a></sup> Based on Moseley and Siegbahn's research, it was also known which atomic numbers corresponded to missing elements yet to be found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moseley2010_137-2"><a href="#cite_note-moseley2010-137">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electron_shells">Electron shells</span></h3>
<p>The Danish physicist <a href="/wiki/Niels_Bohr" title="Niels Bohr">Niels Bohr</a> applied <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck" title="Max Planck">Max Planck</a>'s idea of quantisation to the atom. He concluded that the energy levels of electrons were quantised: only a discrete set of stable energy states were allowed. Bohr then attempted to understand periodicity through electron configurations, surmising in 1913 that the inner electrons should be responsible for the chemical properties of the element.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[133]</a></sup> In 1913, he produced the first electronic periodic table based on a quantum atom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri208_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri208-146">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bohr called his electron shells "rings" in 1913: atomic orbitals within shells did not exist at the time of his planetary model. Bohr explains in Part 3 of his famous 1913 paper that the maximum electrons in a shell is eight, writing, "We see, further, that a ring of n electrons cannot rotate in a single ring round a nucleus of charge ne unless n &lt; 8." For smaller atoms, the electron shells would be filled as follows: "rings of electrons will only join if they contain equal numbers of electrons; and that accordingly the numbers of electrons on inner rings will only be 2, 4, 8." However, in larger atoms the innermost shell would contain eight electrons: "on the other hand, the periodic system of the elements strongly suggests that already in neon N = 10 an inner ring of eight electrons will occur." His proposed electron configurations for the light atoms (shown to the right) do not always accord with those now known.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float:right; font-size:95%; margin:0.5em;">
<caption>Bohr's electron configurations for light elements
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>Element</th>
<th>Electrons per shell
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>4</td>
<td>2,2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>6</td>
<td>2,4
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>7</td>
<td>4,3
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>8</td>
<td>4,2,2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>9</td>
<td>4,4,1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>10</td>
<td>8,2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>11</td>
<td>8,2,1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>16</td>
<td>8,4,2,2
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>18</td>
<td>8,8,2
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The first one to systematically expand and correct the chemical potentials of Bohr's atomic theory was <a href="/wiki/Walther_Kossel" title="Walther Kossel">Walther Kossel</a> in 1914 and in 1916. Kossel explained that in the periodic table new elements would be created as electrons were added to the outer shell. In Kossel's paper, he writes: "This leads to the conclusion that the electrons, which are added further, should be put into concentric rings or shells, on each of which ... only a certain number of electrons—namely, eight in our case—should be arranged. As soon as one ring or shell is completed, a new one has to be started for the next element; the number of electrons, which are most easily accessible, and lie at the outermost periphery, increases again from element to element and, therefore, in the formation of each new shell the chemical periodicity is repeated."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a 1919 paper, <a href="/wiki/Irving_Langmuir" title="Irving Langmuir">Irving Langmuir</a> postulated the existence of "cells" which we now call orbitals, which could each only contain two electrons each, and these were arranged in "equidistant layers" which we now call shells. He made an exception for the first shell to only contain two electrons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[139]</a></sup> The chemist <a href="/wiki/Charles_Rugeley_Bury" title="Charles Rugeley Bury">Charles Rugeley Bury</a> suggested in 1921 that eight and eighteen electrons in a shell form stable configurations. Bury proposed that the electron configurations in transitional elements depended upon the valence electrons in their outer shell.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[140]</a></sup> He introduced the word <i>transition</i> to describe the elements now known as <a href="/wiki/Transition_metal" title="Transition metal">transition metals</a> or transition elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen2003_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen2003-153">[141]</a></sup> The quantum theory clarified the transition metals and lanthanides as forming their own separate groups, transitional between the main groups, although some chemists had already proposed tables showing them this way before then: the English chemist Henry Bassett did so in 1892, the Danish chemist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Julius_Thomsen" title="Julius Thomsen">Julius Thomsen</a> in 1895, and the Swiss chemist <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Werner" title="Alfred Werner">Alfred Werner</a> in 1905. Bohr used Thomsen's form in his 1922 Nobel Lecture; Werner's form is very similar to the modern 32-column form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-3"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Prompted by Bohr, <a href="/wiki/Wolfgang_Pauli" title="Wolfgang Pauli">Wolfgang Pauli</a> took up the problem of electron configurations in 1923. Pauli extended Bohr's scheme to use four <a href="/wiki/Quantum_number" title="Quantum number">quantum numbers</a>, and formulated his <a href="/wiki/Pauli_exclusion_principle" title="Pauli exclusion principle">exclusion principle</a> which stated that no two electrons could have the same four quantum numbers. This explained the lengths of the periods in the periodic table (2, 8, 18, and 32), which corresponded to the number of electrons that each shell could occupy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri218_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri218-154">[142]</a></sup> In 1925, <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Hund" title="Friedrich Hund">Friedrich Hund</a> arrived at configurations close to the modern ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[143]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Aufbau_principle" title="Aufbau principle">Aufbau principle</a> that describes the electron configurations of the elements was first empirically observed by <a href="/wiki/Erwin_Madelung" title="Erwin Madelung">Erwin Madelung</a> in 1926 and published in 1936.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goudsmit_28-3"><a href="#cite_note-Goudsmit-28">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Synthetic_elements">Synthetic elements</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2426" decoding="async" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg/220px-Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg/330px-Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg/440px-Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Glenn_Seaborg_-_1964.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Glenn T. Seaborg</div></div></div>
<p>By then, the pool of missing elements from hydrogen to uranium had shrunk to four: elements 43, 61, 85, and 87 remained missing. Element 43 eventually became the first element to be synthesised artificially via nuclear reactions rather than discovered in nature. It was discovered in 1937 by Italian chemists <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Segr%C3%A8" title="Emilio Segrè">Emilio Segrè</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carlo_Perrier" title="Carlo Perrier">Carlo Perrier</a>, who named their discovery <a href="/wiki/Technetium" title="Technetium">technetium</a>, after the Greek word for "artificial".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[144]</a></sup> Elements 61 (<a href="/wiki/Promethium" title="Promethium">promethium</a>) and 85 (<a href="/wiki/Astatine" title="Astatine">astatine</a>) were likewise produced artificially; element 87 (<a href="/wiki/Francium" title="Francium">francium</a>) became the last element to be discovered in nature, by French chemist <a href="/wiki/Marguerite_Perey" title="Marguerite Perey">Marguerite Perey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[m]</a></sup> The elements beyond uranium were likewise discovered artificially, starting with <a href="/wiki/Edwin_McMillan" title="Edwin McMillan">Edwin McMillan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philip_Abelson" title="Philip Abelson">Philip Abelson</a>'s 1940 discovery of <a href="/wiki/Neptunium" title="Neptunium">neptunium</a> (via bombardment of uranium with neutrons).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri354_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri354-43">[39]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Glenn_T._Seaborg" title="Glenn T. Seaborg">Glenn T. Seaborg</a> and his team at the <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Berkeley_National_Laboratory" title="Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory">Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory</a> (LBNL) continued discovering transuranium elements, starting with <a href="/wiki/Plutonium" title="Plutonium">plutonium</a>, and discovered that contrary to previous thinking, the elements from actinium onwards were congeners of the lanthanides rather than transition metals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seaborg_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-Seaborg-159">[146]</a></sup> Bassett (1892), Werner (1905), and the French engineer <a href="/wiki/Charles_Janet" title="Charles Janet">Charles Janet</a> (1928) had previously suggested this, but their ideas did not then receive general acceptance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-4"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup> Seaborg thus called them the actinides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seaborg_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-Seaborg-159">[146]</a></sup> Elements up to 101 were synthesised either through neutron or alpha-particle irradiation, or in nuclear explosions in the cases of 99 (einsteinium) and 100 (fermium).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri354_43-2"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri354-43">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>A significant controversy arose with elements 102 through 106 in the 1960s and 1970s, as competition arose between the LBNL team (now led by <a href="/wiki/Albert_Ghiorso" title="Albert Ghiorso">Albert Ghiorso</a>) and a team of Soviet scientists at the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Institute_for_Nuclear_Research" title="Joint Institute for Nuclear Research">Joint Institute for Nuclear Research</a> (JINR) led by <a href="/wiki/Georgy_Flyorov" title="Georgy Flyorov">Georgy Flyorov</a>. Each team claimed discovery, and in some cases each proposed their own name for the element, creating an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Element_naming_controversy" title="Element naming controversy">element naming controversy</a> that lasted decades. These elements were made by bombardment of actinides with light ions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[147]</a></sup> IUPAC at first adopted a hands-off approach, preferring to wait and see if a consensus would be forthcoming. Unfortunately, it was also the height of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, and it became clear after some time that this would not happen. As such, IUPAC and the <a href="/wiki/International_Union_of_Pure_and_Applied_Physics" title="International Union of Pure and Applied Physics">International Union of Pure and Applied Physics</a> (IUPAP) created a <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Transfermium_Working_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Transfermium Working Group (page does not exist)">Transfermium Working Group</a> (TWG, fermium being element 100) in 1985 to set out criteria for discovery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[148]</a></sup> After some further controversy, these elements received their final names in 1997, including seaborgium (106) in honour of Seaborg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>The TWG's criteria were used to arbitrate later element discovery claims from research institutes in Germany (<a href="/wiki/GSI_Helmholtz_Centre_for_Heavy_Ion_Research" title="GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research">GSI</a>), Russia (JINR), and Japan (<a href="/wiki/Riken" title="Riken">Riken</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[150]</a></sup> Currently, consideration of discovery claims is performed by a <a href="/wiki/IUPAC/IUPAP_Joint_Working_Party" title="IUPAC/IUPAP Joint Working Party">IUPAC/IUPAP Joint Working Party</a>. After priority was assigned, the elements were officially added to the periodic table, and the discoverers were invited to propose their names.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-6"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> By 2016, this had occurred for all elements up to 118, therefore completing the periodic table's first seven rows.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-7"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-finally_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-finally-164">[151]</a></sup> The discoveries of elements beyond 106 were made possible by techniques devised by <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Oganessian" title="Yuri Oganessian">Yuri Oganessian</a> at the JINR: cold fusion (bombardment of lead and bismuth by heavy ions) made possible the 1981–2004 discoveries of elements 107 through 112 at GSI and 113 at Riken, and he led the JINR team (in collaboration with American scientists) to discover elements 114 through 118 using hot fusion (bombardment of actinides by calcium ions) in 1998–2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapman_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chapman-166">[153]</a></sup> The heaviest known element, oganesson (118), is named in his honour. Element 114 is named flerovium in honour of his predecessor and mentor Flyorov.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapman_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chapman-166">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>In celebration of the periodic table's 150th anniversary, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> declared the year 2019 as the International Year of the Periodic Table, celebrating "one of the most significant achievements in science".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-167">[154]</a></sup> Today, the periodic table is among the most recognisable icons of chemistry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lemonick_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lemonick-168">[155]</a></sup> IUPAC is involved today with many processes relating to the periodic table: the recognition and naming of new elements, recommending group numbers and collective names, determining which elements belong to group 3, and the updating of atomic weights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-8"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_questions">Current questions</span></h2>
<p>Although the modern periodic table is standard today, some variation can be found in period 1 and group 3. Discussion is ongoing about the placements of  the relevant elements. The controversy has to do with conflicting understandings of whether chemical or electronic properties should primarily decide periodic table placement, and conflicting views of how the evidence should be used.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lemonick_168-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lemonick-168">[155]</a></sup> A similar potential problem has been raised by theoretical investigations of the superheavy elements, whose chemistries may not fit their present position on the periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sciencemag_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag-169">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Period_1">Period 1</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Period_1_element" title="Period 1 element">Period 1 element</a></div>
<p>Usually, hydrogen is placed in group 1, and helium in group 18: this is the placement found on the IUPAC periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-9"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> Some variation can be found on both these matters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KW_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-KW-170">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>Like the group 1 metals, hydrogen has one electron in its outermost shell<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gray12_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gray12-171">[158]</a></sup> and typically loses its only electron in chemical reactions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vlasov_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vlasov-172">[159]</a></sup> It has some metal-like chemical properties, being able to displace some metals from their <a href="/wiki/Salt_(chemistry)" title="Salt (chemistry)">salts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vlasov_172-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vlasov-172">[159]</a></sup> But hydrogen forms a diatomic nonmetallic gas at standard conditions, unlike the alkali metals which are reactive solid metals. This and hydrogen's formation of <a href="/wiki/Hydride" title="Hydride">hydrides</a>, in which it gains an electron, brings it close to the properties of the <a href="/wiki/Halogen" title="Halogen">halogens</a> which do the same. Moreover, the lightest two halogens (<a href="/wiki/Fluorine" title="Fluorine">fluorine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chlorine" title="Chlorine">chlorine</a>) are gaseous like hydrogen at standard conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vlasov_172-2"><a href="#cite_note-Vlasov-172">[159]</a></sup> Hydrogen thus has properties corresponding to both those of the alkali metals and the halogens, but matches neither group perfectly, and is thus difficult to place by its chemistry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vlasov_172-3"><a href="#cite_note-Vlasov-172">[159]</a></sup> Therefore, while the electronic placement of hydrogen in group 1 predominates, some rarer arrangements show either hydrogen in group 17,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[160]</a></sup> duplicate hydrogen in both groups 1 and 17,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaesz_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kaesz-175">[162]</a></sup> or float it separately from all groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kaesz_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kaesz-175">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GE_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-GE-176">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KW_170-1"><a href="#cite_note-KW-170">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>Helium is an unreactive noble gas at standard conditions, and has a full outer shell: these properties are like the noble gases in group 18, but not at all like the reactive alkaline earth metals of group 2. Therefore, helium is nearly universally placed in group 18<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-10"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> which its properties best match.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KW_170-2"><a href="#cite_note-KW-170">[157]</a></sup> However, helium only has two outer electrons in its outer shell, whereas the other noble gases have eight; and it is an s-block element, whereas all other noble gases are p-block elements. Also, solid helium crystallises in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hexagonal_close-packed" title="Hexagonal close-packed">hexagonal close-packed</a> structure, which matches beryllium and magnesium in group 2, but not the other noble gases in group 18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kurushkin_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kurushkin-177">[164]</a></sup> In these ways helium better matches the alkaline earth metals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gray12_171-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gray12-171">[158]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KW_170-3"><a href="#cite_note-KW-170">[157]</a></sup> Therefore, tables with both hydrogen and helium floating outside all groups may rarely be encountered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GE_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-GE-176">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KW_170-4"><a href="#cite_note-KW-170">[157]</a></sup> A few chemists have advocated that the electronic placement in group 2 be adopted for helium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kurushkin_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kurushkin-177">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[168]</a></sup> Arguments for this often rest on the first-row anomaly trend, as helium as the first s<sup>2</sup> element before the alkaline earth metals stands out as anomalous in a way that helium as the first noble gas does not.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-1"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Group_3">Group 3</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Group_3_element" title="Group 3 element">Group 3 element</a></div>

</td>

</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Oganesson" title="Oganesson"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Oganesson</span></a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</div></div>
</div>
<p>Published periodic tables show variation regarding the heavier members of group 3, which begins with scandium and yttrium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-2"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup> They are most commonly lanthanum and actinium, but there are many physical and chemical arguments that they should instead be lutetium and lawrencium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen1982_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen1982-182">[169]</a></sup> A compromise can also sometimes be found, in which the spaces below yttrium are left blank. This leaves it ambiguous if the group only contains scandium and yttrium,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sesqui_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-sesqui-183">[170]</a></sup> or if it also extends to include all thirty lanthanides and actinides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-5"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="micro-periodic-table-title" role="navigation" style="float:right; background:#f8f8f8; padding:0.3em; border:1px solid #a9a9a9; margin:0 0 0.25em 0.5em; text-align:center;;">
<div id="micro-periodic-table-title" style="background:#d8d8d8; padding:0.15em 0.3em; font-size:90%; line-height:110%; font-weight:bold;">Sc, Y</div>
