<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Rutherfordium" title="Rutherfordium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Rutherfordium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Dubnium" title="Dubnium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Dubnium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Seaborgium" title="Seaborgium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Seaborgium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Bohrium" title="Bohrium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Bohrium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Hassium" title="Hassium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Hassium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Meitnerium" title="Meitnerium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Meitnerium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Darmstadtium" title="Darmstadtium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Darmstadtium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Roentgenium" title="Roentgenium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Roentgenium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Copernicium" title="Copernicium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#99ccff;">Copernicium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Nihonium" title="Nihonium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Nihonium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Flerovium" title="Flerovium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Flerovium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Moscovium" title="Moscovium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Moscovium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Livermorium" title="Livermorium"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Livermorium</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Tennessine" title="Tennessine"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Tennessine</span></a>
</td>
<td style="border:none;padding:0;"><a href="/wiki/Oganesson" title="Oganesson"><span style="display:block;width:6px;height:8px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;color:transparent;background-color:#fdff8c;">Oganesson</span></a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
</div></div>
</div>
<p>Lanthanum was initially placed as the first of the 5d elements as its configuration ([Xe]5d<sup>1</sup>6s<sup>2</sup>) added a d-electron to the preceding element, barium ([Xe]6s<sup>2</sup>). This made it the third member of group 3, with cerium to lutetium then following as the f-block, which then split the d-block in two. Meanwhile, based on the configurations known at that time, it was thought that lutetium ([Xe]4f<sup>14</sup>5d<sup>1</sup>6s<sup>2</sup>) added the final 4f electron to ytterbium's configuration (then thought to be [Xe]4f<sup>13</sup>5d<sup>1</sup>6s<sup>2</sup>). Thus the d-block was split into two: after lanthanum filled the first d-electron, cerium to lutetium followed as the f-block, before the d-block resumed with hafnium through mercury.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen1982_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen1982-182">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>But in 1937, it was found that the configuration of ytterbium had been determined erroneously, and was actually [Xe]4f<sup>14</sup>6s<sup>2</sup>. That meant that the 4f subshell completed filling at ytterbium rather than at lutetium as had previously been thought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-3"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup> As such, in 1948 the Soviet physicists <a href="/wiki/Lev_Landau" title="Lev Landau">Lev Landau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evgeny_Lifshitz" title="Evgeny Lifshitz">Evgeny Lifshitz</a> pointed out in their <i><a href="/wiki/Course_of_Theoretical_Physics" title="Course of Theoretical Physics">Course of Theoretical Physics</a></i> that the new configurations suggested that the first 5d element was lutetium and not lanthanum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-4"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[171]</a></sup> This avoids the d-block split by letting the f-block (now lanthanum through ytterbium) precede the d-block (lutetium through mercury) in accordance with the Aufbau principle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-6"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup> Such a placement had previously been adopted by Werner in 1905 (though lutetium had not yet been discovered) and by Janet in 1928.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-7"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup> The early appearance of a d-electron in lanthanum could then simply be considered another case of an anomalous configuration; supporting this argument, the majority of the lanthanides and actinides have an f<sup><i>x</i></sup>s<sup>2</sup> configuration rather than an f<sup><i>x</i>−1</sup>d<sup>1</sup>s<sup>2</sup> one in the ground state, as one would expect if the f-block began at lanthanum and its configuration were merely an exception to the general rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-johnson_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-johnson-185">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[n]</a></sup> Several physicists and chemists in the following decades supported this reassignment based on other physical and chemical properties of the elements involved,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS2_106-4"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS2-106">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-5"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup> although this evidence has in turn been criticised as having been selectively chosen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-6"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup> Most authors did not make the change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-7"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1988, a IUPAC report was published that touched on the matter. While it wrote that electron configurations were in favour of the new assignment of group 3 with lutetium and lawrencium, it instead decided on a compromise where the lower spots in group 3 were instead left blank, because the traditional form with lanthanum and actinium remained popular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fluck_50-2"><a href="#cite_note-Fluck-50">[46]</a></sup> This is similar to Brauner's 1902 asteroid hypothesis;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thyssen_54-8"><a href="#cite_note-Thyssen-54">[50]</a></sup> it makes the f-block appear with 15 elements despite quantum mechanics dictating that it should have 14, and leaves it unclear if group 3 contains only scandium and yttrium, or if it contains all lanthanides and actinides in addition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2021IUPAC_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-2021IUPAC-187">[173]</a></sup> The following <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IUPAC_Red_Book" title="IUPAC Red Book">IUPAC Red Book</a> (a collection of nomenclature rules for inorganic chemistry) of 1990 displayed the periodic table in three formats, 8-column (based on Mendeleev's original), 18-column, and 32-column; the first two showed the compromise with all lanthanides and actinides in group 3, but the third showed lutetium and lawrencium alone under yttrium in group 3.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[174]</a></sup> In 2005, the 8-column and 32-column forms were dropped from the IUPAC Red Book, leaving only the compromise version in 18-column format.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-11"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>The IUPAC compromise did not stop the debate. Most sources focusing on the question supported the reassignment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen2015_37-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen2015-37">[33]</a></sup> but some authors argued instead in favour of the traditional form with lanthanum as the first 5d element,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS_178-8"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS-178">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lemonick_168-2"><a href="#cite_note-Lemonick-168">[155]</a></sup> sometimes giving rise to furious debate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-raynercanham_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-raynercanham-190">[176]</a></sup> A minority of textbooks accepted the reassignment, but most either showed the older form or the IUPAC compromise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-2015IUPAC-56">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2015 IUPAC began a project to decide whether lanthanum or lutetium should go in group 3, chaired by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Scerri" title="Eric Scerri">Eric Scerri</a>, a chemist and philosopher of science of Maltese origin. It considered the question to be "of considerable importance" for chemists, physicists, and students, noting that the variation in published periodic tables on this point typically puzzled students and instructors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-2"><a href="#cite_note-2015IUPAC-56">[52]</a></sup> A provisional report appeared from it in 2021, which was in favour of lutetium as the first 5d element. The reasons given were to display all elements in order of increasing atomic number, avoid the d-block split, and to have the blocks follow the widths quantum mechanics demands of them (2, 6, 10, and 14).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2021IUPAC_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-2021IUPAC-187">[173]</a></sup> The project ended that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-3"><a href="#cite_note-2015IUPAC-56">[52]</a></sup> Currently, IUPAC's website on the periodic table still shows the 1988 compromise, but mentions the group 3 problem and project to resolve it, and writes "Stay tune[d]".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-12"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Superheavy_elements">Superheavy elements</span></h3>
<p>Although all elements up to oganesson (element 118) have been discovered, the chemistry of the elements beyond <a href="/wiki/Hassium" title="Hassium">hassium</a> (element 108) is not well-understood. Of these, only <a href="/wiki/Copernicium" title="Copernicium">copernicium</a> (element 112), <a href="/wiki/Nihonium" title="Nihonium">nihonium</a> (element 113), and <a href="/wiki/Flerovium" title="Flerovium">flerovium</a> (element 114) have been experimentally investigated; these investigations so far have not produced conclusive results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRNL_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-CRNL-84">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the elements past hassium may behave differently from what would be predicted by extrapolation, due to <a href="/wiki/Relativistic_quantum_chemistry" title="Relativistic quantum chemistry">relativistic</a> effects. For example, extrapolation would suggest that copernicium and flerovium behave as metals, like their respective lighter congeners mercury and lead. Some predictions considering relativistic effects agree, but other such predictions expect them to possibly exhibit some noble-gas-like properties, even though neither is placed in group 18 with the other noble gases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRNL_84-2"><a href="#cite_note-CRNL-84">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schändel_2003_277_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-Schändel_2003_277-113">[102]</a></sup> The current experimental evidence still leaves the question open.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRNL_84-3"><a href="#cite_note-CRNL-84">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[177]</a></sup> Oganesson (element 118) has been predicted to be a solid semiconductor at standard conditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-semiconductor_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-semiconductor-86">[79]</a></sup> similar to <a href="/wiki/Silicon" title="Silicon">silicon</a> in group 14,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-primefan2_112-1"><a href="#cite_note-primefan2-112">[101]</a></sup> despite being in group 18; no experiments have been done to confirm or refute this prediction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-semiconductor_86-2"><a href="#cite_note-semiconductor-86">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some scientists have argued that should these superheavy elements truly have different properties than their position on the periodic table suggests, the periodic table should be altered to place them with more chemically similar elements. On the other hand, others have argued that the periodic table should reflect atomic structure rather than chemical properties, and oppose such a change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sciencemag_169-1"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag-169">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_extension_beyond_the_seventh_period">Future extension beyond the seventh period</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Extended_periodic_table" title="Extended periodic table">Extended periodic table</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Island_of_stability" title="Island of stability">Island of stability</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:422px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1006" data-file-width="1304" decoding="async" height="324" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg/420px-Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg/630px-Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg/840px-Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg.png 2x" width="420"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pyykko_periodic_table_172.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>One possible form of the extended periodic table to element 172, suggested by Finnish chemist <a href="/wiki/Pekka_Pyykk%C3%B6" title="Pekka Pyykkö">Pekka Pyykkö</a>. Deviations from the Madelung order (8s &lt; 5g &lt; 6f &lt; 7d &lt; 8p) begin to appear at elements 139 and 140,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PT172_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-PT172-192">[178]</a></sup> though for the most part it continues to hold approximately.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-recentattempts_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-recentattempts-193">[179]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The most recently named elements – nihonium (113), moscovium (115), tennessine (117), and oganesson (118) – completed the seventh row of the periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-13"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> Future elements would have to begin an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Period_8_element" title="Period 8 element">eighth row</a>. These elements may be referred to either by their atomic numbers (e.g. "element 119"), or by the IUPAC <a href="/wiki/Systematic_element_name" title="Systematic element name">systematic element names</a> which directly relate to the atomic numbers (e.g. "ununennium" for element 119, derived from Latin <i>unus</i> "one", Greek <i>ennea</i> "nine", and the traditional <i>-ium</i> suffix for metallic elements).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUPAC-redbook_8-14"><a href="#cite_note-IUPAC-redbook-8">[8]</a></sup> All attempts to synthesise such elements have failed so far. An attempt to make element 119 has been ongoing since 2018 at the <a href="/wiki/Riken" title="Riken">Riken</a> research institute in Japan. The Joint Institute for Nuclear Research in Russia also plans to make its own attempts at synthesising the first few period 8 elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nature2019_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-nature2019-194">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SHEfactory_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-SHEfactory-195">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>Currently, discussion continues if this future eighth period should follow the pattern set by the earlier periods or not, as calculations predict that by this point relativistic effects should result in significant deviations from the Madelung rule. Various different models have been suggested. All agree that the eighth period should begin like the previous ones with two 8s elements, and that there should then follow a new series of g-block elements filling up the 5g orbitals, but the precise configurations calculated for these 5g elements vary widely between sources. Beyond this 5g series, calculations do not agree on what exactly should follow. Filling of the 5g, 6f, 7d, and 8p shells is expected to occur in approximately that order, but they are likely to be intermingled with each other and with the 9s and 9p subshells, so that it is not clear which elements should go in which groups anymore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fricke_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fricke-198">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PT172_192-1"><a href="#cite_note-PT172-192">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nefedov_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-nefedov-199">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-recentattempts_193-1"><a href="#cite_note-recentattempts-193">[179]</a></sup> Scerri has raised the question of whether an extended periodic table should take into account the failure of the Madelung rule in this region, or if such exceptions should be ignored.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-recentattempts_193-2"><a href="#cite_note-recentattempts-193">[179]</a></sup> The shell structure may also be fairly formal at this point: already the electron distribution in an oganesson atom is expected to be rather uniform, with no discernible shell structure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oganesson-elf_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-oganesson-elf-200">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nuclear stability will likely prove a decisive factor constraining the number of possible elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[o]</a></sup> It depends on the balance between the electric repulsion between protons and the strong force binding protons and neutrons together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[189]</a></sup> Protons and neutrons are arranged in <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_shell_model" title="Nuclear shell model">shells</a>, just like electrons, and so a closed shell can significantly increase stability: the known superheavy nuclei exist because of such a shell closure. They are probably close to a predicted <a href="/wiki/Island_of_stability" title="Island of stability">island of stability</a>, where superheavy nuclides should have significantly longer half-lives: predictions range from minutes or days, to millions or billions of years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-physorg_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-physorg-205">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nuclei_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-nuclei-206">[191]</a></sup> However, as the number of protons increases beyond about 126, this stabilising effect should vanish as a closed shell is passed. It is not clear if any further-out shell closures exist, due to an expected smearing out of distinct nuclear shells (as is already expected for the electron shells at oganesson).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-relqed_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-relqed-207">[192]</a></sup> Furthermore, even if later shell closures exist, it is not clear if they would allow such heavy elements to exist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greinernuclei_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-greinernuclei-208">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-radiochimica_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-radiochimica-209">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTSS1_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-PTSS1-210">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_103-3"><a href="#cite_note-EB-103">[93]</a></sup> As such, it may be that the periodic table practically ends around element 120, as elements become too short-lived to observe; the era of discovering new elements would thus be close to its end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_103-4"><a href="#cite_note-EB-103">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alternatively, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quark_matter" title="Quark matter">quark matter</a> may become stable at high mass numbers, in which the nucleus is composed of freely flowing <a href="/wiki/Up_quark" title="Up quark">up</a> and <a href="/wiki/Down_quark" title="Down quark">down quarks</a> instead of binding them into protons and neutrons; this would create a <a href="/wiki/Continent_of_stability" title="Continent of stability">continent of stability</a> instead of an island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-udQM_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-udQM-212">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-udQMnew_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-udQMnew-213">[198]</a></sup> Other effects may come into play: for example, in very heavy elements the 1s electrons are likely to spend a significant amount of time so close to the nucleus that they are actually inside it, which would make them vulnerable to <a href="/wiki/Electron_capture" title="Electron capture">electron capture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-colloq_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-colloq-214">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Even if eighth-row elements can exist, producing them is likely to be difficult, and it should become even more difficult as atomic number rises.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[200]</a></sup> Although the 8s elements are expected to be reachable with present means, the first few 5g elements are expected to require new technology,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zagrebaev_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zagrebaev-216">[201]</a></sup> if they can be produced at all.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomberg_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomberg-217">[202]</a></sup> Experimentally characterising these elements chemically would also pose a great challenge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nature2019_194-1"><a href="#cite_note-nature2019-194">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Alternative_periodic_tables">Alternative periodic tables</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Alternative_periodic_tables" title="Alternative periodic tables">Alternative periodic tables</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Elementspiral_(polyatomic).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="790" data-file-width="928" decoding="async" height="298" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Elementspiral_%28polyatomic%29.svg/350px-Elementspiral_%28polyatomic%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Elementspiral_%28polyatomic%29.svg/525px-Elementspiral_%28polyatomic%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Elementspiral_%28polyatomic%29.svg/700px-Elementspiral_%28polyatomic%29.svg.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Elementspiral_(polyatomic).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Otto_Theodor_Benfey" title="Otto Theodor Benfey">Otto Theodor Benfey</a>'s spiral periodic table (1964)</div></div></div>
<p>The periodic law may be represented in multiple ways, of which the standard periodic table is only one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[203]</a></sup> Within 100 years of the appearance of Mendeleev's table in 1869, <a href="/wiki/Edward_G._Mazurs" title="Edward G. Mazurs">Edward G. Mazurs</a> had collected an estimated 700 different published versions of the periodic table.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen_107-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen-107">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Papers_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-Papers-219">[204]</a></sup> Many forms retain the rectangular structure, including Janet's left-step periodic table (pictured below), and the modernised form of Mendeleev's original 8-column layout that is still common in Russia. Other periodic table formats have been shaped much more exotically, such as spirals (<a href="/wiki/Otto_Theodor_Benfey" title="Otto Theodor Benfey">Otto Theodor Benfey</a>'s pictured to the right), circles, triangles, and even elephants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alternative periodic tables are often developed to highlight or emphasize chemical or physical properties of the elements that are not as apparent in traditional periodic tables, with different ones skewed more towards emphasizing chemistry or physics at either end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri402_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri402-221">[206]</a></sup> The standard form, which remains by far the most common, is somewhere in the middle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri402_221-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri402-221">[206]</a></sup>
</p><p>The many different forms of the periodic table have prompted the questions of whether there is an optimal or definitive form of the periodic table, and if so what it might be. There are no current consensus answers to either question, though several forms have been suggested as optimal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sesqui_183-1"><a href="#cite_note-sesqui-183">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scerri402_221-2"><a href="#cite_note-Scerri402-221">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-optimal_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-optimal-222">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-collapsible uncollapsed" style="background:#f8f8f8; font-size:90%; border:1px solid #a9a9a9; width:100%; max-width:1800px; margin:0 auto; padding:2px; vertical-align:top;">
<div style="background:#d8d8d8; padding:2px 4px;font-weight:bold; text-align:center;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-collapse navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Periodic_table_(left_step)" title="Template:Periodic table (left step)"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Periodic_table_(left_step)" title="Template talk:Periodic table (left step)"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Periodic_table_(left_step)&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div class="navbar-ct-mini">Left-step periodic table (by Charles Janet)</div></div><div class="mw-collapsible-content">

</td>
<td style="background:#ff9999"><a href="/wiki/Unbinilium" title="Unbinilium">120</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="33" style="height:7px; border-bottom:1px solid black">
</td></tr>
<tr style="font-size:90%; line-height:100%;">
<td>
</td>
<td colspan="14" style="background:#9bff99"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-block" title="F-block">f-block</a>
</td>
<td colspan="10" style="background:#99ccff"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D-block" title="D-block">d-block</a>
</td>
<td colspan="6" style="background:#fdff8c"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P-block" title="P-block">p-block</a>
</td>
<td colspan="2" style="background:#ff9999"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S-block" title="S-block">s-block</a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
This form of periodic table is congruent with the order in which electron shells are ideally filled according to the <a href="/wiki/Aufbau_principle#Madelung_energy_ordering_rule" title="Aufbau principle">Madelung rule</a>, as shown in the accompanying sequence in the left margin (read from top to bottom, left to right). The experimentally determined ground-state electron configurations of the elements differ from the configurations predicted by the Madelung rule in twenty instances, but the Madelung-predicted configurations are always at least close to the ground state. The last two elements shown, elements 119 and 120, have not yet been synthesized.</div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The question of how many natural elements there are is quite complicated and is not fully resolved. In the early Solar System, shorter-lived elements had not yet decayed away, and consequently there were more than 94 naturally occurring elements. <a href="/wiki/Curium" title="Curium">Curium</a> (element 96) is the longest-lived element beyond the first 94, and is probably still being brought to Earth via <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_ray" title="Cosmic ray">cosmic rays</a>, but it has not been found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThorntonBurdette_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-ThorntonBurdette-10">[10]</a></sup> Elements up to 99 (<a href="/wiki/Einsteinium" title="Einsteinium">einsteinium</a>) have been observed in <a href="/wiki/Przybylski%27s_Star" title="Przybylski's Star">Przybylski's Star</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gopka08_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-gopka08-11">[11]</a></sup> Elements up to 100 (<a href="/wiki/Fermium" title="Fermium">fermium</a>) probably occurred in the <a href="/wiki/Natural_nuclear_fission_reactor" title="Natural nuclear fission reactor">natural nuclear fission reactor</a> at <a href="/wiki/Oklo_Mine" title="Oklo Mine">Oklo Mine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gabon" title="Gabon">Gabon</a>, but they have long since decayed away.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emsley_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-emsley-12">[12]</a></sup> Even heavier elements may be produced in the <a href="/wiki/R-process" title="R-process">r-process</a> via <a href="/wiki/Supernova" title="Supernova">supernovae</a> or <a href="/wiki/Neutron_star_merger" title="Neutron star merger">neutron star mergers</a>, but this has not been confirmed. It is not clear how far they would extend past 100 and how long they would last.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> If such <a href="/wiki/Superheavy_element" title="Superheavy element">superheavy elements</a> are sufficiently long-lived, they might similarly be brought to Earth via cosmic rays, but again none have been found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThorntonBurdette_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-ThorntonBurdette-10">[10]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tiny traces of <a href="/wiki/Plutonium" title="Plutonium">plutonium</a> are also continually brought to Earth via cosmic rays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WallnerFaestermann2015_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-WallnerFaestermann2015-15">[14]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Strictly speaking, one cannot draw an orbital such that the electron is guaranteed to be inside it, but it can be drawn to guarantee a 90% probability of this for example.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[20]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
Once two to four electrons are removed, the d and f orbitals usually become lower in energy than the s ones:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jorgensen-33">[30]</a></sup>
<dl><dd>1s ≪ 2s &lt; 2p ≪ 3s &lt; 3p ≪ 3d &lt; 4s &lt; 4p ≪ 4d &lt; 5s &lt; 5p ≪ 4f &lt; 5d &lt; 6s &lt; 6p ≪ 5f &lt; 6d &lt; 7s &lt; 7p ≪ ...</dd></dl>

and in the limit for extremely highly charged ions, orbitals simply fill in the order of increasing <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span> instead. There is a gradual transition between the limiting situations of highly charged ions (increasing <span class="texhtml mvar" style="font-style:italic;">n</span>) and neutral atoms (Madelung's rule).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goudsmit_28-2"><a href="#cite_note-Goudsmit-28">[25]</a></sup>
<dl><dd></dd></dl>
Also, the ordering of the orbitals between each ≪ changes somewhat throughout each period. For example, the ordering in argon and potassium is 3p ≪ 4s &lt; 4p ≪ 3d; by calcium it has become 3p ≪ 4s &lt; 3d &lt; 4p; from scandium to copper it is 3p ≪ 3d &lt; 4s &lt; 4p; and from zinc to krypton it is 3p &lt; 3d ≪ 4s &lt; 4p<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cao_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cao-32">[29]</a></sup> as the d-orbitals fall into the core at gallium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[31]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See for example <a class="external text" href="https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/SG/en/product/aldrich/z543209" rel="nofollow">the periodic table poster sold by Sigma-Aldrich.</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There are many lower oxides as well: for example, <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">phosphorus</a> in group 15 forms two oxides, <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus_trioxide" title="Phosphorus trioxide">P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub></a> and <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus_pentoxide" title="Phosphorus pentoxide">P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub></a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwood27_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwood27-58">[53]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-78">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">All this describes the situation at standard pressure. Under sufficiently high pressure, the band gaps of any solid drop to zero and metallisation occurs. Thus for example at about 170 <a href="/wiki/Bar_(unit)" title="Bar (unit)">kbar</a> iodine becomes a metal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siekierski_76-4"><a href="#cite_note-Siekierski-76">[70]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Metallic_hydrogen" title="Metallic hydrogen">metallic hydrogen</a> should form at pressures of about four million atmospheres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[71]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Descriptions of the structures formed by the elements can be found throughout Greenwood and Earnshaw. There are two borderline cases. Arsenic's most stable form conducts electricity like a metal, but the bonding is significantly more localised to the nearest neighbours than it is for the similar structures of antimony and bismuth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[80]</a></sup> Carbon as <a href="/wiki/Graphite" title="Graphite">graphite</a> shows metallic conduction parallel to its planes, but is a semiconductor perpendicular to them.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Melting_points_of_the_elements_(data_page)" title="Melting points of the elements (data page)">melting points of the elements (data page)</a>. The same is probably true of francium, but due to its extreme instability, this has never been experimentally confirmed.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Lists_of_metalloids" title="Lists of metalloids">lists of metalloids</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Classification can change even within a single work. For example, Sherwin and Weston's <i>Chemistry of the Non-Metallic Elements</i> (1966) has a periodic table on p. 7 classifying antimony as a nonmetal, but on p. 115 it is called a metal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[94]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-transition_metal" title="Post-transition metal">post-transition metal</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-158">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Technetium, promethium, astatine, neptunium, and plutonium were eventually discovered to occur in nature as well, albeit in tiny traces. See <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_chemical_element_discoveries" title="Timeline of chemical element discoveries">timeline of chemical element discoveries</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-186">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">An analogous situation occurs for the actinides. Here not only actinium ([Rn]6d<sup>1</sup>7s<sup>2</sup>) but also thorium ([Rn]6d<sup>2</sup>7s<sup>2</sup>) fail to fill the 5f shell in the ground-state configuration; since thorium is universally treated as an f-block element even by those who exclude lanthanum and actinium, it has been argued that the lack of valence f electrons in the ground-state configuration should not be an absolute prohibition against being an f-block element. The first 5f electron occurs at protactinium ([Rn]5f<sup>2</sup>6d<sup>1</sup>7s<sup>2</sup>), and the 5f shell finishes filling at nobelium ([Rn]5f<sup>14</sup>7s<sup>2</sup>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen1982_182-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen1982-182">[169]</a></sup> Lawrencium ([Rn]5f<sup>14</sup>7s<sup>2</sup>7p<sup>1</sup>) is an exception either way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen2015_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jensen2015-37">[33]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-203">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A simplistic interpretation of the <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_relativity" title="Theory of relativity">relativistic</a> <a href="/wiki/Dirac_equation" title="Dirac equation">Dirac equation</a> runs into problems with electron orbitals at <i>Z</i> &gt; 1/α ≈ 137; this would suggest that that neutral atoms cannot exist beyond element 137, and that a periodic table of elements based on electron orbitals therefore breaks down at this point.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[187]</a></sup> However, this argument presumes that the atomic nucleus is pointlike. A more accurate calculation must take into account the small, but nonzero, size of the nucleus, which pushes the limit to <i>Z</i> = 173. Moreover, it turns out that the prohibition is not against neutral atoms, but against bare nuclei: elements with atomic number beyond 173 cannot be totally ionised because their 1s shell would be filled by spontaneous electron–positron <a href="/wiki/Pair_production" title="Pair production">pair production</a>, but encounter no difficulties if their 1s shell is already filled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[188]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-CIAAW2021-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CIAAW2021_2-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFProhaskaIrrgeherBenefieldBöhlke2022">Prohaska, Thomas; Irrgeher, Johanna; Benefield, Jacqueline; Böhlke, John K.; Chesson, Lesley A.; Coplen, Tyler B.; Ding, Tiping; Dunn, Philip J. </li>
<li id="cite_note-FIII2-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FIII2_3-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFeynmanLeightonSands1964">Feynman, Richard; Leighton, Robert B.; Sands, Matthew (1964). </li>
<li id="cite_note-FI2-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FI2_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FI2_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FI2_4-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFeynmanLeightonSands1964">Feynman, Richard; Leighton, Robert B.; Sands, Matthew (1964). "2. Basic Physics". <a class="external text" href="https://feynmanlectures.caltech.edu/I_02.html" rel="nofollow"><i>The Feynman Lectures on Physics</i></a>. Vol. 1. Addison–Wesley. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-201-02115-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-201-02115-3"><bdi>0-201-02115-3</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20140328044256/http://www.feynmanlectures.caltech.edu/I_02.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 28 March 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 August</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=2.+Basic+Physics&amp;rft.btitle=The+Feynman+Lectures+on+Physics&amp;rft.pub=Addison%E2%80%93Wesley&amp;rft.date=1964&amp;rft.isbn=0-201-02115-3&amp;rft.aulast=Feynman&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.au=Leighton%2C+Robert+B.&amp;rft.au=Sands%2C+Matthew&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Ffeynmanlectures.caltech.edu%2FI_02.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-cartoon-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-9"><sup><i><b>j</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-10"><sup><i><b>k</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-11"><sup><i><b>l</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-12"><sup><i><b>m</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-13"><sup><i><b>n</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-14"><sup><i><b>o</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-15"><sup><i><b>p</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-16"><sup><i><b>q</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-17"><sup><i><b>r</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-18"><sup><i><b>s</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-19"><sup><i><b>t</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cartoon_5-20"><sup><i><b>u</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGonickCriddle2005">Gonick, First; Criddle, Craig (2005). <i>The Cartoon Guide to Chemistry</i>. Collins. pp. 17–65. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-06-093677-0" title="Special:BookSources/0-06-093677-0"><bdi>0-06-093677-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cartoon+Guide+to+Chemistry&amp;rft.pages=17-65&amp;rft.pub=Collins&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=0-06-093677-0&amp;rft.aulast=Gonick&amp;rft.aufirst=First&amp;rft.au=Criddle%2C+Craig&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/periodic%20law" rel="nofollow">"periodic law"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster" title="Merriam-Webster">Merriam-Webster Dictionary</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-Jensen2009-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Jensen2009_19-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jensen2009_19-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFJensen2009"><a href="/wiki/William_B._Jensen" title="William B. <li id="cite_note-Cao-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Cao_32-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Cao_32-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCaoVernonSchwarzLi2021">Cao, Changsu; Vernon, René E.; Schwarz, W. H. <li id="cite_note-Jorgensen-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jorgensen_33-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFJørgensen1973">Jørgensen, Christian (1973). "The Loose Connection between Electron Configuration and the Chemical Behavior of the Heavy Elements (Transuranics)". <i>Angewandte Chemie International Edition</i>. <b>12</b> (1): 12–19. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fanie.197300121" rel="nofollow">10.1002/anie.197300121</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Angewandte+Chemie+International+Edition&amp;rft.atitle=The+Loose+Connection+between+Electron+Configuration+and+the+Chemical+Behavior+of+the+Heavy+Elements+%28Transuranics%29&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=12-19&amp;rft.date=1973&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1002%2Fanie.197300121&amp;rft.aulast=J%C3%B8rgensen&amp;rft.aufirst=Christian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFTossell1977">Tossell, J.A. (1 November 1977). "Theoretical studies of valence orbital binding energies in solid zinc sulfide, zinc oxide, and zinc fluoride". <i>Inorganic Chemistry</i>. <b>16</b> (11): 2944–2949. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1021%2Fic50177a056" rel="nofollow">10.1021/ic50177a056</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Inorganic+Chemistry&amp;rft.atitle=Theoretical+studies+of+valence+orbital+binding+energies+in+solid+zinc+sulfide%2C+zinc+oxide%2C+and+zinc+fluoride&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=11&amp;rft.pages=2944-2949&amp;rft.date=1977-11-01&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1021%2Fic50177a056&amp;rft.aulast=Tossell&amp;rft.aufirst=J.A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Petrucci326-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Petrucci326_36-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Petrucci326_36-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Petrucci et al., pp. 326–7</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-pp2002-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-pp2002_45-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFOganessian,_Yu._T.2002">Oganessian, Yu. T.;  et al. (2002). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20041213100709/http://www.jinr.ru/publish/Preprints/2002/287%28D7-2002-287%29e.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Results from the first <span class="chemf nowrap"><span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:0.5em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left"><sup style="font-size:inherit;line-height:inherit;vertical-align:baseline">249</sup><br/><sub style="font-size:inherit;line-height:inherit;vertical-align:baseline"></sub></span>Cf</span>+<span class="chemf nowrap"><span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:0.5em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left"><sup style="font-size:inherit;line-height:inherit;vertical-align:baseline">48</sup><br/><sub style="font-size:inherit;line-height:inherit;vertical-align:baseline"></sub></span>Ca</span> experiment"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>JINR Communication</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 June</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=JINR+Communication&amp;rft.atitle=Results+from+the+first+%3Cspan+class%3D%22chemf+nowrap%22%3E%3Cspan+style%3D%22display%3Ainline-block%3Bmargin-bottom%3A-0.3em%3Bvertical-align%3A0.5em%3Bline-height%3A1em%3Bfont-size%3A80%25%3Btext-align%3Aleft%22%3E%3Csup+style%3D%22font-size%3Ainherit%3Bline-height%3Ainherit%3Bvertical-align%3Abaseline%22%3E249%3C%2Fsup%3E%3Cbr+%2F%3E%3Csub+style%3D%22font-size%3Ainherit%3Bline-height%3Ainherit%3Bvertical-align%3Abaseline%22%3E%3C%2Fsub%3E%3C%2Fspan%3ECf%3C%2Fspan%3E%2B%3Cspan+class%3D%22chemf+nowrap%22%3E%3Cspan+style%3D%22display%3Ainline-block%3Bmargin-bottom%3A-0.3em%3Bvertical-align%3A0.5em%3Bline-height%3A1em%3Bfont-size%3A80%25%3Btext-align%3Aleft%22%3E%3Csup+style%3D%22font-size%3Ainherit%3Bline-height%3Ainherit%3Bvertical-align%3Abaseline%22%3E48%3C%2Fsup%3E%3Cbr+%2F%3E%3Csub+style%3D%22font-size%3Ainherit%3Bline-height%3Ainherit%3Bvertical-align%3Abaseline%22%3E%3C%2Fsub%3E%3C%2Fspan%3ECa%3C%2Fspan%3E+experiment&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.au=Oganessian%2C+Yu.+T.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.jinr.ru%2Fpublish%2FPreprints%2F2002%2F287%28D7-2002-287%29e.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-2015IUPAC-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-2015IUPAC_56-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://iupac.org/projects/project-details/?project_nr=2015-039-2-200" rel="nofollow">"The constitution of group 3 of the periodic table"</a>. <li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMessler2010">Messler, R. <li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHawkes2001">Hawkes, Stephen J. (2001). <li id="cite_note-CRNL-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CRNL_84-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CRNL_84-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CRNL_84-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CRNL_84-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMewesSmitsKresseSchwerdtfeger2019">Mewes, J.-M.; Smits, O. <li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFlorezSmitsMewesJerabek2022">Florez, Edison; Smits, Odile R.; Mewes, Jan-Michael; Jerabek, Paul; Schwerdtfeger, Peter (2022). <li id="cite_note-semiconductor-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-semiconductor_86-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-semiconductor_86-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-semiconductor_86-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMewesSmitsJerabekSchwerdtfeger2019">Mewes, Jan-Michael; <li id="cite_note-Holl-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Holl_90-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFHollemanWiberg,_EgonWiberg,_Nils1985">Holleman, Arnold F.; Wiberg, Egon; Wiberg, Nils (1985). Walter de Gruyter. pp. 1110–1117. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-11-007511-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-11-007511-3"><bdi>978-3-11-007511-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Mangan&amp;rft.btitle=Lehrbuch+der+Anorganischen+Chemie&amp;rft.pages=1110-1117&amp;rft.edition=91%E2%80%93100&amp;rft.pub=Walter+de+Gruyter&amp;rft.date=1985&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-11-007511-3&amp;rft.aulast=Holleman&amp;rft.aufirst=Arnold+F.&amp;rft.au=Wiberg%2C+Egon&amp;rft.au=Wiberg%2C+Nils&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-wiberg_holleman-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-wiberg_holleman_91-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWiberg,_EgonWiberg,_NilsHolleman,_Arnold_Frederick2001">Wiberg, Egon; Wiberg, Nils &amp; Holleman, Arnold Frederick (2001). <i>Inorganic chemistry</i>. <li id="cite_note-PTSS2-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-PTSS2_106-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PTSS2_106-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PTSS2_106-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PTSS2_106-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PTSS2_106-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Scerri, pp. 407–420</span>

<li id="cite_note-Jensen-107"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Jensen_107-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Jensen_107-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFJensen1986">Jensen, William B. (1986). <a class="external text" href="http://www.che.uc.edu/Jensen/W.%20B.%20Jensen/Reprints/028.%20Periodic%20Table.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Classification, symmetry and the periodic table"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Comp. &amp; Maths. With Appls</i>. <b>12B</b> (I/2). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170131184706/http://www.che.uc.edu/Jensen/W.%20B.%20Jensen/Reprints/028.%20Periodic%20Table.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 31 January 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 January</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Comp.+%26+Maths.+With+Appls.&amp;rft.atitle=Classification%2C+symmetry+and+the+periodic+table&amp;rft.volume=12B&amp;rft.issue=I%2F2&amp;rft.date=1986&amp;rft.aulast=Jensen&amp;rft.aufirst=William+B.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.che.uc.edu%2FJensen%2FW.%2520B.%2520Jensen%2FReprints%2F028.%2520Periodic%2520Table.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 August</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Pure+and+Applied+Chemistry&amp;rft.atitle=How+to+name+new+chemical+elements&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=info%3Ahdl%2F10045%2F55935&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A102245448%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1515%2Fpac-2015-0802&amp;rft.aulast=Koppenol&amp;rft.aufirst=W.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Frua.ua.es%2Fdspace%2Fbitstream%2F10045%2F55935%2F1%2F2016_Koppenol_etal_PureApplChem.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRoth2018">Roth, Klaus (3 April 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.chemistryviews.org/details/ezine/10907570/New_Kids_on_the_Table_Is_Element_118_a_Noble_Gas__Part_1.html" rel="nofollow">"Is Element 118 a Noble Gas?"</a>. <i>Chemie in unserer Zeit</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fchemv.201800029" rel="nofollow">10.1002/chemv.201800029</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210302084128/https://www.chemistryviews.org/details/ezine/10907570/New_Kids_on_the_Table_Is_Element_118_a_Noble_Gas__Part_1.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 2 March 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-122"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-122">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFThe_Chemical_Society_of_Japan2018">The Chemical Society of Japan (25 January 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.chemistry.or.jp/news/information/1-2.html" rel="nofollow">"【お知らせ】高等学校化学で用いる用語に関する提案（1）への反応"</a>. <i>www.chemistry.or.jp</i>. The Chemical Society of Japan. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210516062728/https://www.chemistry.or.jp/news/information/1-2.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 16 May 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 April</span> 2021</span>. <q>「12．アルカリ土類金属」の範囲についても，△を含めれば，すべての教科書で提案が考慮されている。歴史的には第4 周期のカルシウム以下を指していた用語だったが，「周期表の2 族に対応する用語とする」というIUPAC の勧告1）に従うのは現在では自然な流れだろう。</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.chemistry.or.jp&amp;rft.atitle=%E3%80%90%E3%81%8A%E7%9F%A5%E3%82%89%E3%81%9B%E3%80%91%E9%AB%98%E7%AD%89%E5%AD%A6%E6%A0%A1%E5%8C%96%E5%AD%A6%E3%81%A7%E7%94%A8%E3%81%84%E3%82%8B%E7%94%A8%E8%AA%9E%E3%81%AB%E9%96%A2%E3%81%99%E3%82%8B%E6%8F%90%E6%A1%88%EF%BC%881%EF%BC%89%E3%81%B8%E3%81%AE%E5%8F%8D%E5%BF%9C&amp;rft.date=2018-01-25&amp;rft.au=The+Chemical+Society+of+Japan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.chemistry.or.jp%2Fnews%2Finformation%2F1-2.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-123"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-123">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFWurzer1817">Wurzer, Ferdinand (1817). <a class="external text" href="https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=chi.096071138;view=1up;seq=351" rel="nofollow">"Auszug eines Briefes vom Hofrath Wurzer, Prof. der Chemie zu Marburg"</a> [Excerpt of a letter from Court Advisor Wurzer, Professor of Chemistry at Marburg]. <i>Annalen der Physik</i> (in German). <b>56</b> (7): 331–334. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1817AnP....56..331." rel="nofollow">1817AnP....56..331.</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fandp.18170560709" rel="nofollow">10.1002/andp.18170560709</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211008024621/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=chi.096071138;view=1up;seq=351" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 8 October 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 August</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Annalen+der+Physik&amp;rft.atitle=Auszug+eines+Briefes+vom+Hofrath+Wurzer%2C+Prof.+der+Chemie+zu+Marburg&amp;rft.volume=56&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.pages=331-334&amp;rft.date=1817&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1002%2Fandp.18170560709&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1817AnP....56..331.&amp;rft.aulast=Wurzer&amp;rft.aufirst=Ferdinand&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbabel.hathitrust.org%2Fcgi%2Fpt%3Fid%3Dchi.096071138%3Bview%3D1up%3Bseq%3D351&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span> Here, Döbereiner found that strontium's properties were intermediate to those of calcium and barium.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFDöbereiner1829">Döbereiner, J. W. (1829). <a class="external text" href="https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015065410634;view=1up;seq=315" rel="nofollow">"Versuch zu einer Gruppirung der elementaren Stoffe nach ihrer Analogie"</a> [An attempt to group elementary substances according to their analogies]. <i>Annalen der Physik und Chemie</i>. 2nd series (in German). <b>15</b> (2): 301–307. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1829AnP....91..301D" rel="nofollow">1829AnP....91..301D</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fandp.18290910217" rel="nofollow">10.1002/andp.18290910217</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211008024625/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015065410634;view=1up;seq=315" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 8 October 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-mendeleev1871-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-mendeleev1871_132-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFMendeleev1871">Mendeleev, D. <li id="cite_note-135"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-135">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFRouvray">Rouvray, R. <a class="external text" href="https://www.newscientist.com/people/dmitri-mendeleev/" rel="nofollow">"Dmitri Mendeleev"</a>. <i>New Scientist</i>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210815074119/https://www.newscientist.com/people/dmitri-mendeleev/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 15 August 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Scerri164-136"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Scerri164_136-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Scerri, pp. 164–169</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-moseley2010-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-moseley2010_137-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-moseley2010_137-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-moseley2010_137-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation magazine cs1" id="CITEREFMarshallMarshall2010">Marshall, J.L.; Marshall, V.R. (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190716215907/https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/afe4/8822cd0871e65dc5401166e7df68dc0ecb7f.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Rediscovery of the Elements: Moseley and Atomic Numbers"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>The Hexagon</i>. Vol. 101, no. 3. <a href="/wiki/Alpha_Chi_Sigma" title="Alpha Chi Sigma">Alpha Chi Sigma</a>. pp. 42–47. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:94398490" rel="nofollow">94398490</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/afe4/8822cd0871e65dc5401166e7df68dc0ecb7f.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 16 July 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 August</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Hexagon&amp;rft.atitle=Rediscovery+of+the+Elements%3A+Moseley+and+Atomic+Numbers&amp;rft.volume=101&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=42-47&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A94398490%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Marshall&amp;rft.aufirst=J.L.&amp;rft.au=Marshall%2C+V.R.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fpdfs.semanticscholar.org%2Fafe4%2F8822cd0871e65dc5401166e7df68dc0ecb7f.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-138"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-138">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A. van der Broek, Physikalische Zeitschrift, 14, (1913), 32-41</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-139"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-139">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Scerri, p. 185</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A. van der Broek, Die Radioelemente, das periodische System und die Konstitution der Atom, Physik. Zeitsch., 14, 32, (1913).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">E. Rutherford, Phil. Mag., 27, 488-499 (Mar. 1914). "This has led to an interesting suggestion by van Broek that the number of units of charge on the nucleus, and consequently the number of external electrons, may be equal to the number of the elements when arranged in order of increasing atomic weight. On this view, the nucleus charges of hydrogen, helium, and carbon are 1, 2, 6 respectively, and so on for the other elements, provided there is no gap due to a missing element. This view has been taken by Bohr in his theory of the constitution of simple atoms and molecules."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAtkins,_P._W.1995"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P._W._Atkins" title="P. W. Atkins">Atkins, P. W.</a> (1995). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/periodickingdomj00atki/page/87" rel="nofollow"><i>The Periodic Kingdom</i></a>. HarperCollins Publishers, Inc. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/periodickingdomj00atki/page/87" rel="nofollow">87</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-465-07265-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-465-07265-1"><bdi>978-0-465-07265-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Periodic+Kingdom&amp;rft.pages=87&amp;rft.pub=HarperCollins+Publishers%2C+Inc.&amp;rft.date=1995&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-465-07265-1&amp;rft.au=Atkins%2C+P.+W.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fperiodickingdomj00atki%2Fpage%2F87&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFEgdellBruton2020">Egdell, Russell G.; Bruton, Elizabeth (2020). <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fchem.202004775" rel="nofollow">"Henry Moseley, X-ray spectroscopy and the periodic table"</a>. <i>Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences</i>. <b>378</b> (2180). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1002%2Fchem.202004775" rel="nofollow">10.1002/chem.202004775</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32811359" rel="nofollow">32811359</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Philosophical+Transactions+of+the+Royal+Society+A%3A+Mathematical%2C+Physical+and+Engineering+Sciences&amp;rft.atitle=Henry+Moseley%2C+X-ray+spectroscopy+and+the+periodic+table&amp;rft.volume=378&amp;rft.issue=2180&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1002%2Fchem.202004775&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F32811359&amp;rft.aulast=Egdell&amp;rft.aufirst=Russell+G.&amp;rft.au=Bruton%2C+Elizabeth&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1002%252Fchem.202004775&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-163"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-163">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHofmann2019">Hofmann, Sigurd (2019). <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1515%2Fci-2019-0103" rel="nofollow">"Criteria for New Element Discovery"</a>. <i>Chemistry International</i>. <b>41</b> (1): 10–15. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1515%2Fci-2019-0103" rel="nofollow">10.1515/ci-2019-0103</a></span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Chemistry+International&amp;rft.atitle=Criteria+for+New+Element+Discovery&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=10-15&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1515%2Fci-2019-0103&amp;rft.aulast=Hofmann&amp;rft.aufirst=Sigurd&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1515%252Fci-2019-0103&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APeriodic+table"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-GE-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-GE_176-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-GE_176-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Greenwood &amp; Earnshaw, throughout the book</span>
